docTitle.titlePart: THE RETURN OF PETER GRIMM A PLAY IN THREE ACTS By DAVID BELASCO

[ The Editor wishes to thank Mr. David Belasco for his courtesy in granting permission to include “ The Return of Peter Grimm ” in the present Collection . All its rights are fully secured , and proceedings will immediately be taken against any one attempting to infringe them . ]

div.head: ACT I .

stage.stage: The scene shows a comfortable living-room in an old house . The furniture was brought to America by PETER GRIMM 'S ancestors . The GRIMMS were , for the most part , frugal people , but two or three fine paintings have been inherited by PETER .

A small , old-fashioned piano stands near the open window , a few comfortable chairs , a desk with a hanging lamp above it , and an arm-chair in front of it , a quaint old fireplace , a Dutch wall clock with weights , a sofa , a hat-rack , and mahogany flower-pot holders , are set about the room ; but the most treasured possession is a large family Bible lying on a table . A door leads to a small office occupied by PETER 'S secretary .

Stairs lead to the sleeping-rooms above . Through the window , hothouses , beds of tulips , and other flowers , shrubs and trees are seen . “ Peter Grimm 's Botanic Gardens ” supply seeds , plants , shrubbery and trees to the wholesale , as well as retail trade , and the view suggests the importance of the industry . An old Dutch windmill , erected by a Colonial ancestor , gives a quaint touch , to the picture . Although PETER GRIMM is a very wealthy man , he lives as simply as his ancestors .

As the curtain is raised , the room is empty ; but CATHERINE is heard singing in the dining-room . JAMES HARTMAN , PETER 'S secretary , opens his door to listen , a small bundle of letters in his hand . He is a well set up young man , rather blunt in his manner , and a trifle careless in his dress . After a pause , he goes back into the office , leaving the door ajar . Presently CATHERINE enters . In spite of her youth and girlish appearance , she is a good , thrifty housekeeper . She wears a simple summer gown , and carries a bunch of gay tulips and an old silver pitcher , from which she presently pours water into the Harlequin Delft vase on PETER GRIMM 'S desk . She peeps into the office , retreating , with a smile on her lips , as JAMES appears .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Did I disturb you , James ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: On the threshold .No indeed .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Do you like your new work ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Anything to get back to the gardens , Catherine . I 've always done outside work and I prefer it ; but I would shovel dirt rather than work for any one else .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Amused .James !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: It 's true . When the train reached the Junction , and a boy presented the passengers with the usual flower and the “ compliments of Peter Grimm ” — it took me back to the time when that was my job ; and when I saw the old sign , “ Grimm 's Botanic Gardens and Nurseries ” — I wanted to jump off the train and run through the grounds . It seemed as though every tulip called “ hello ” to me .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Too bad you left college ! You had only one more year .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Poor father ! He 's very much disappointed . Father has worked in the dirt in overalls — a gardener — all his life ; and , of course , he over-estimates an education . He 's far more intelligent than most of our college professors .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I understand why you came back . You simply must live where things grow , must n't you , James ? So must I . Have you seen our orchids ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Orchids are pretty ; but they 're doing wonderful things with potatoes these days . I 'd rather improve the breed of a squash than to have an orchid named after me . Wonderful discovery of Luther Burbank 's — creating an edible cactus . Sometimes I feel bitter thinking what I might have done with vegetables , when I was wasting time studying Greek .

lg.l: James : why do n't you try to please Uncle
Peter Grimm ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do ; but he is always asking my opinion , and when I give it , he blows up .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Coaxingly .Do n't be quite so blunt . Try to be like one of the family .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'm afraid I shall never be like one of this family .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Why not ? I 'm no relation at all ; and yet —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Making a resolution .I 'll do my best to agree with him .Offering his hand .They shake hands .It 's a promise .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Thank you , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Still holding her hand .It 's good to be back , Catherine . It 's good to see you again . He is still holding her hand when FREDERIK GRIMM enters . He is the son of PETER 'S dead sister , and has been educated by PETER to carry on his work . He is a graduate of Amsterdam College , Holland , and , in appearance and manner , suggests the foreign student . He has managed to pull through college creditably , making a specialty of botany . PETER has given him the usual trip through Europe , and FREDERIK has come to his rich uncle to settle down and learn his business . He has been an inmate of the household for a few months . He poses as a most industrious young man , but is , at heart , a shirker .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Where 's Uncle ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Good-morning , Frederik . Your uncle 's watching father spray the plum trees . The black knot 's after them again .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I can hardly keep my eyes open . Uncle wakes me up every morning at five — creaking down the old stairs .Eyeing CATHERINE admiringly .CATHERINE edges away and runs upstairs to her room .You 're looking uncommonly pretty this morning , Kitty .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Hartman !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Miss Catherine and you and I are no longer children — our positions are altered — please remember that . I 'm no longer a student home for the holidays from Amsterdam College . I 'm here to learn the business which I am expected to carry on . Miss Catherine is a young lady now , and my uncle looks upon her as his daughter . You are here as my uncle 's secretary . That 's how we three stand in this house . Do n't call me “ Frederik , ” and hereafter be good enough to say , “ Miss Grimm . ”

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Amiably .Very well .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: James : there 's a good opportunity for a young man like you in our Florida house . I think that if I spoke for you —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Why do you wish to ship me off to Florida ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I do n't understand you , Hartman . I do n't wish to ship you off . I am merely thinking of your future . You seem to have changed since —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: JAMES has laid some mail on the desk , and is about to leave the room , when FREDERIK speaks again , but in a more friendly manner .We 've all grown up , as you just said .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: The old man 's aging ; do you notice it ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Your uncle 's mellowing , yes ; but that 's only to be expected . He 's changing foliage with the years .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: He 's growing as old-fashioned as his hats . In my opinion , this would be the time to sell .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Astonished .Sell ? Sell a business that has been in his family for — why , it 's his religion !

lg.l: It 's at the height of its prosperity . It would sell like that !
What was the last offer the old man refused from
Hicks , of Rochester , Jim ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Noticing the sudden friendliness — looking at FREDERIK , half-amused , half-disgusted .Ca n't repeat correspondence , Mr. Grimm .Amazed .Good heavens ! You surprise me ! Would you sell your great , great grandfather ? I learned to read by studying his obituary out in the peach orchard : “ Johann Grimm , of Holland , an upright settler . ” There is n't a day your uncle does n't tell me that you are to carry on the work .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: So I am , but it 's not my religion .Sarcastically ..Every man can n't be blessed like you with the soul of a market gardener — a peddler of turnips .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Thinking — ignoring FREDERIK .He 's a great old man — your uncle . It 's a big name — Grimm — Peter Grimm . The old man knows his business — he certainly knows his business .Changing .God ! It 's an awful thought that a man must die and carry all that knowledge of orchids to the grave ! I wonder if it does n't all count somewhere .... I must attend to the mail . PETER GRIMM enters from the gardens . He is a well-preserved man of sixty , very simple and plain in his ways . He has not changed his style of dress in the past thirty years . His clothing , collar , tie , hat and shoes are all old-fashioned . He is an estimable man , scrupulously honest , gentle and sympathetic ; but occasionally he shows a flash of Dutch stubbornness .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I ran over from the office , Uncle Peter , to make a suggestion .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I suggest that we insert a full-page cut of your new tulip in our mid-summer floral almanac .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Who has hung up his hat on his own particular peg , affably assenting .A good idea !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: The public is expecting it .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You think so , my boy ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Why , Uncle , you 've no idea of the stir this tulip has created . People stop me in the street to speak of it .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well , well , you surprise me . I did n't think it so extraordinary .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I 've had a busy morning , sir , in the packing house .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: That 's good . I 'm glad to see you taking hold of things , Fritz .Humourously , touching FREDERIK affectionately on the shoulder .We must n't waste time ; for that 's the stuff life 's made of .Seriously .It 's a great comfort to me , Frederik , to know that when I 'm in my little private room with James , or when I 've slipped out to the hothouses ,— you are representing me in the offices — young Mr. Grimm .... James , are you ready for me ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I 'll attend to the mail in a moment .Missing CATHERINE , he calls according to the household signal .Ou — oo !He is answered by CATHERINE , who immediately appears from her room , and comes running downstairs .Catherine , I have news for you . I 've named the new rose after you : “ Katie — a hardy bloomer . ” It 's as red as the ribbon in your hair .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Thank you , Uncle Peter , thank you very much . And now you must have your cup of coffee .

lg.l: What a fine little housewife ! A busy girl about the house , eh ,
Fritz ? Is there anything you need to-day , Katie ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: No , Uncle Peter , I have everything I need , thank you .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Not everything ,— not everything , my dear .Smiling at FREDERIK . JAMES , ignored , is standing in the background .Wait ! Wait till I give you a husband . I have my plans .Looking from FREDERIK to CATHERINE .People do n't always know what I 'm doing , but I 'm a great man for planning . Come , Katie , tell me , on this fine spring morning , what sort of husband would you prefer ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Annoyed ,— with girlish impatience .You 're always speaking of weddings , Uncle Peter . I do n't know what 's come over you of late .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: It 's nesting time , ... spring weddings are in the air ; besides , my grandmother 's linen-chest upstairs must be used again for youImpulsively drawing CATHERINE to him ., my house fairy .Kisses her .There , I must n't tease her . But I leave it to Fritz if I do n't owe her a fine husband — this girl of mine . Look what she has done for me !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Done for you ? I do you the great favour to let you do everything for me .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ah , but who lays out my linen ? Who puts flowers on my desk every day ? Who gets up at dawn to eat breakfast with me ? Who sees that I have my second cup of coffee ? But better than all that — who brings youth into my old house ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: That 's not much — youth .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No ? We 'll leave it to Fritz .FREDERIK , amused , listens in silence .What should I be now — a rough old fellow — a bachelor — without youth in my house , eh ? God knows ! Katie has softened me towards all the ladies — er — mellowed me as time has mellowed my old pictures .Points to pictures .And I was growing hard — hard and fussy .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Laughing .Ah , Uncle Peter , have I made you take a liking to all the rest of the ladies ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes . It 's just as it is when you have a pet : you like all that breed . You can only see your kind of kitten .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Coming down a step , impressed by PETER 'S remark — speaking earnestly .That 's so , sir .The others are surprised .I had n't thought of it in that way , but it 's true . You study a girl for the first time , and presently you notice the same little traits in every one of them . It makes you feel differently towards all the rest .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Amused .Why , James , what do you know about girls ? “ Bachelor ” is stamped all over you — you 're positively labelled .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Good-naturedly .Goes back to the office .Perhaps .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Poor James ! What a life before him ! When a bachelor wants to order a three-rib roast , who 's to eat it ? I never had a proper roast until Katie and Frederik came to make up my family ;Rubbing his hands .but the roasts are not big enough .Giving FREDERIK a knowing look .We must find a husband .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: You promised not to —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I want to see a long , long table with plenty of young people .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I 'll leave the room , Uncle .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: With myself at the head , carving , carving , carving , watching the plates come back , and back , and back .As she is about to go .There , there , not another word of this to-day . The ‘ phone rings . JAMES re-enters and answers it .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Hello !Turns .Rochester asks for Mr. Peter Grimm to the ‘ phone . Another message from Hicks ’ greenhouses .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ask them to excuse me .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Bluntly .You 'll have to excuse him .Listens .No , no , the gardens are not in the market . You 're only wasting your time .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: JAMES listens at ‘ phone .Tc ! Tc ! James ! Ca n't you say it politely ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Aside to PETER .James is so painfully blunt .Then changing .Is it — er — a good offer ? Is Hicks willing to make it worth while ?Catching his uncle 's astonished eye — apologetically .Of course , I know you would n't think of —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I should say not ! My home ? An offer ? Our gardens ? I should say not !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Mere curiosity on my part , that 's all .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Of course , I understand . Sell out ? No indeed . We are thinking of the next generation .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Certainly , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: We 're the last of the family . The business — that 's Peter Grimm . It will soon be Frederik Grimm . The love for the old gardens is in our blood .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Lays a fond hand on PETER 'S shoulder .It is , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Struck .I have an idea . We 'll print the family history in our new floral almanac .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Suppressing a yawn .Yes , yes , a very good idea .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Katie , read it to us and let us hear how it sounds .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Reads .“ In the spring of 1709 there settled on Quassick Creek , New York State , Johann Grimm , aged twenty-two , husbandman and vine-dresser , also Johanna , his wife . ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Very interesting .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Very interesting , indeed .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: “ To him Queen Anne furnished one square , one rule , one compass , two whipping saws and several small pieces . To him was born — ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Interrupting .You left out two augurs .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Reads .Oh , yes — “ and two augurs . To him was born a son — ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Who knows the history by heart , has listened , his eyes almost suffused — repeating each word to himself , as she reads . He has lived over each generation down to the present and nods in approval as she reaches this point .The foundation of our house . And here we are prosperous and flourishing — after seven generations . We 'll print it , eh , Fritz ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Certainly , sir . By all means let us print it .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: And now we are depending upon you , Frederik , for the next line in the book .To CATHERINE — slyly — as she closes the book .If my sister could see Frederik , what a proud mother she would be !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Turning from the ‘ phone to PETER .Old man Hicks himself has come to the ‘ phone . Says he must speak to Mr. Peter Grimm .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I 'd make short work of him , Uncle .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: At the ‘ phone .How are you , my old friend ?... How are your plum trees ?Listens .Bad , eh ? Well , we can only pray and use Bordeaux Mixture .... No .... Nonsense ! This business has been in my family for seven generations . Why sell ? I 'll see that it stays in the family seven generations longer !Echoing .Do I propose to live that long ? N — no ; but my plans will .Looks towards FREDERIK and CATHERINE .Hangs up the receiver .How ? Never mind . Good-morning .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Sorry to disturb you , sir , but some of these letters are —

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I 'm off .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Who has lifted a pot of tulips to set it in the sun — standing with the pot in his hands .And remember the saying :A twinkle in his upraised eyes .Smells the tulips and sets them down .“ Thou , O God , sellest all good things at the price of labour . ”

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Goes briskly towards the door .That 's true , sir . I want to speak to you later , Uncle —Turning , looking at JAMES .He goes off looking at his watch , as though he had a hard day 's work before him .on a private matter .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Looking after FREDERIK .Very capable young fellow , Frederik . I was a happy man , James , when I heard that he had won the prize for botany at Amsterdam College . I had to find out the little I know by experience .

lg.stage: Catching a warning glance from CATHERINE , he pauses .
lg.l: Yes , and I 'll wager you 've forgotten more than —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Nothing , sir . I —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Tugging at PETER 'S coat — speaking to him apart , as JAMES busies himself at the desk .Uncle Peter , I think you 're unfair to James . We used to have him to dinner very often before he went away . Now that he 's back , you treat him like a stranger .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Surprised .Eh ? I did n't know that I —Petting CATHERINE .A good , unselfish girl . She thinks of everybody .Aloud .James , will you have dinner with us to-day ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Pleased and surprised .Thank you , sir — yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: It 's a roast goose — cooked sweet , James .Smacks his lips .Fresh green herbs in the dressing and a Figaro pudding . Marta brought over that pudding receipt from Holland . MARTA , an old family servant , has entered with the air of having forgotten to wind the clock . She smiles happily at PETER 'S allusion to her puddings , attends to the old clock , and passes of with CATHERINE . PETER sits at the desk , glancing over the mail .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Katie 's blossoming like a rose . Have you noticed how she 's coming out lately , James ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Picks up another letter , looking over it .You 've noticed it , too ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Pausing , taking off his eye-glasses and holding them on his thumb . Philosophically .How prettily Nature accomplishes her will — making a girl doubly beautiful that a young man may yield his freedom the more easily . Wonderful !During the following , he glances over letters .A young girl is like a violet sheltered under a bush , James ; and that is as it should be , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , sir , I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Surprised .What ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I believe people should think for themselves — not be ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Go on .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: — er —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Remembering his promise to CATHERINE .Nothing .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Go on , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I mean swallowed up .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Swallowed up ? Explain yourself , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I should n't have mentioned it .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Certainly , certainly . Do n't be afraid to express an honest opinion .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I only meant that you can n't shape another 's life . We are all free beings and —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Free ? Of course Katie 's free — to a certain extent . Do you mean to tell me that any young girl should be freer ? Nonsense ! She should be happy that I am here to think for her — I ! We must think for people who can n't think for themselves ; and a young girl can n't .Signing an answer to a letter after hastily glancing over it .You have extraordinary ideas , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Excuse me , sir ; you asked my opinion . I only meant that we can n't think for others — any more than we can eat or sleep for them .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: As though accepting the explanation .Oh ... I see what you mean .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Giving PETER another letter to sign .Of course , every happy being is bound by its nature to lead its own life — that it may be a free being . Evidently I did n't make my meaning clear .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Free ? Happy ? James , you talk like an anarchist ! You surprise me , sir . Where do you get these extraordinary ideas ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: By reading modern books and magazines , sir , and of course —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I thought so .Pointing to his books .Read Heine . Cultivate sentiment .Signing the letter .Happy ? Has it ever occurred to you that Katie is not happy ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , sir , I can n't truthfully say that it has .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I imagine not . These are the happiest hours of her life . Young ... in love ... soon to be married .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: After a long pause .Is it settled , sir ?

lg.l: No , but I 'll soon settle it . Anyone can see how she feels towards
Frederik .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: After a shorter pause .Is n't she very young to marry , sir ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Not when she marries into the family ; not when I am in the house —Touching his chest .to guard her — to watch over her . Leave it to me .Enthusiastically .Sit here , James . Take one of Frederik 's cigars .JAMES politely thanks him , but does n't take one .It 's a pleasure to talk to some one who 's interested ; and you are interested , James ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , sir , I 'm much more interested than you might think .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good . We 'll take up the mail in a minute . Now , in order to carry out my plans —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Sticking her head in the door .Ready for coffee ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Er — a little later . Close the door , dear .She disappears , closing the door .In order to carry out my plans , I have had to use great diplomacy . I made up my mind to keep Katie in the family ; being a rich man — everybody knows it — I 've had to guard against fortune-hunters . However , I think I 've done away with them , for the whole town understands that Katie has n't a penny — does n't it , James ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , I think I 've made that very clear . My dream was to bring Catherine up to keep her in the family , and it has been fulfilled . My plans have turned out beautifully , for she is satisfied and happy .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: But did you want her to be happy simply because you are happy , sir ? Do n't you want her to be happy because she is happy ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Picks up the last letter .If she 's happy , why should I care ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: If she 's happy .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Losing his temper .What do you mean ? That 's the second time you 've said that . Why do you harp on —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Rising .Excuse me , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Angrily .Sit down . What do you know ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Nothing , sir ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You must know something to speak in this manner .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , I do n't . You 're a great expert in your line , Mr. Grimm , and I have the greatest respect for your opinion ; but you can n't mate people as you 'd graft tulips . And more than once , I 've — I 've caught her crying and I 've thought perhaps ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Pooh-poohing .Crying ? Of course ! Was there ever a girl who did n't cry ?... You amuse me ... with your ideas of life .... Ha ! Have n't I asked her why she was crying ,— and has n't she always said : “ I do n't know why — it 's nothing . ” They love to cry .Signs the last letter .But that 's what they all cry over — nothing . James , do you know how I happened to meet Katie ? She was prescribed for me by Doctor MacPherson .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Taking the letter .Prescribed ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: As an antidote . I was growing to be a fussy bachelor , with queer notions . You are young , but see that you do n't need the Doctor , James . Do you know how I was cured ? I 'll tell you . One day , when I had business in the city , the Doctor went with me , and before I knew what he was at — he had marched me into a home for babies .... Katie was nearest the door — the first one . Pinned over her crib was her name : “ Catherine Staats , aged three months . ” She held out her little arms ... so friendless — so pitiful — so alone — and I was done for . We brought her back home , the Doctor , a nurse and I . The first time I carried her up those stairs — all my fine bachelor 's ideas went out of my head . I knew then that my theories were all humbug . I had missed the child in the house who was to teach me everything . I had missed many children in my house . From that day , I watched over her life .Rising , pointing towards the head of the stairs .James , I was born in this house — in the little room where I sleep ; and her children shall one day play in the room in which I was born .... That 's very pretty , eh ?Wipes his eyes , sentimentally .I 've always seen it that way .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Coolly .Yes ; it 's very pretty if it turns out well .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: How can it turn out otherwise ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: To me , sir , it 's not a question of sentiment — of where her children shall play , so long as they play happily .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What ? Her children can play anywhere — in China if they want to ! Are you in your senses ? A fine reward for giving a child all your affection — to live to see her children playing in China . No , sir ! I propose to keep my household together , by your leave .Banging his clenched fist on the desk .It 's my plan .Cleans his pipe , looking at JAMES from time to time . JAMES posts the letters in a mail-box outside the door . PETER goes to the window , calling off .Otto ! Run to the office and tell Mr. Frederik he may come in now .The voice of a gruff Dutchman : “ Het is pastoor 's dag . ” ( It is the pastor 's day .] Ah , yes ; I had forgotten . It 's William 's day to take flowers to the Pastor .A knock is heard and , as PETER calls “ Come in , ” WILLIAM , a delicate child of eight , stands timidly in the doorway of the dining-room , hat in hand .Pats WILLIAM on the shoulder .How are you to-day , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: The Doctor says I 'm well now .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good ! Then you shall take flowers to the church .Calls off .A big armful , Otto ! MARTA has entered with a neatly folded , clean handkerchief which she tucks into WILLIAM 'S breast pocket .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: In a low voice , to JAMES .There 's your example of freedom ! William 's mother , old Marta 's spoiled child , was free . You remember Annamarie , James ?— let to come and go as she pleased . God knows where she is now ... and here is William with the poor old grandmother .... Run along with the flowers , William .Gives WILLIAM some pennies as he goes .How he shoots up , eh , Marta ?

lg.stage: With the hopeless sorrow of the old , as she passes off .
lg.l: Poor child ... poor child .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Give Katie more freedom , eh ? Oh , no ! I shall guard her as I would guard my own , for she is as dear to me as though she were mine , and , by marriage , please God , she shall be a Grimm in name .

lg.l: Mr. Grimm , I — I wish you would transfer me to your branch house in
Florida .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What ? You who were so glad to come back ! James , you need a holiday . Close your desk . Go out and busy yourself with those pet vegetables of yours . Change your ideas ; then come back sane and sensible , and attend to your work .Giving a last shot at JAMES as he passes into the office and FREDERIK re-enters .You do n't know what you want !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Looking after JAMES .Uncle Peter , when I came in this morning , I made up my mind to speak to you of James .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: James ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Yes , I 've wondered lately if ... it seems to me that James is interested in Catherine .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: James ? Impossible .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I 'm not so sure .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good-naturedly .James ? James Hartman ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: When I look back and remember him as a barefoot boy living in a shack behind our hot-houses — and see him now — in here with you —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: All the more credit , Frederik .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Yes ; but these are the sort of fellows who dream of getting into the firm . And there are more ways than one .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Do you mean to say — He would n't presume to think of such a thing .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Oh , would n't he ! The class to which he belongs presumes to think of anything . I believe he has been making love to Catherine .

lg.stage: After a slight pause , goes to the dining-room door and calls .
lg.l: Katie ! Katie !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Hastily .CATHERINE enters .Do n't say that I mentioned it .

lg.l: Katie , I wish to ask you a question . I —
Oh , it 's absurd . No , no , never mind .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I can n't ask you . It 's really too absurd .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Her curiosity aroused .What is it , Uncle ?... Tell me ... tell me ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Has James ever —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Taken back and rather frightened — quickly .No ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What ?... How did you know what I ...FREDERIK gives her a shrewd glance ; but PETER , suspecting nothing , continues .I meant ... has James shown any special interest in you ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: As though accepting the explanation .Oh ...Flurried .Why , Uncle Peter !... Uncle Peter !... whatever put this notion into your head ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: It 's all nonsense , of course , but —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I 've always known James .... We went to school together .... James has shown no interest he ought not to have shown , Uncle Peter ,— if that 's what you mean . He has always been very respectful in a perfectly friendly way .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Convinced .Respectful in a perfectly friendly way .To FREDERIK .You can n't ask more than that . Thank you , dear , that 's all I wanted . Run along .Glad to escape , CATHERINE leaves the room .He was only respectful in a perfectly friendly way .Slaps FREDERIK on the back .You 're satisfied now , I hope ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: No , I am not . If she has n't noticed what he has in mind , I have . When I came into this room a few moments ago ,— it was as plain as day . He 's trying to make love to her under our very eyes . I saw him . I wish you would ask him to stay in his office and attend to his own business .JAMES now re-enters on his way to the gardens .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: James , it has just occurred to me — that —James pauses .What was your reason for wanting to give up your position ? Had it anything to do with my little girl ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You mean that — you — you love her ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: In a low voice .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: FREDERIK gives PETER a glance as though to say , “ Now , do you believe it ? ”O-ho !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: But she does n't know it , of course ; she never would have known it . I never meant to say a word to her . I understand , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: James ! Come here ... here !...Bringing JAMES up before him at the desk .Get your money at the office . You may have that position in Florida . Good-bye , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'm very sorry that ... Good-bye , sir .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: You are not to tell her that you 're going . You 're not to bid her good-bye .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: To FREDERIK .Sh ! Let me attend to —

lg.l: I 'm sorry , Mr. Grimm , that —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Rising .Shakes hands with JAMES , who leaves the room too much overcome to speak .James , I 'm sorry , too . You 've grown up here and — Tc ! Tc ! Good fortune to you — James . Get this notion out of your head , and perhaps one day you 'll come back to us . We shall see .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Who has entered , saying carelessly to JAMES as he passes him .Hy 're you , Jim ? Glad Jim 's back . One of the finest lads I ever brought into this world . The DOCTOR is a man of about PETER 'S age , but more powerfully built . He has the bent shoulders of the student and his face is exceedingly intellectual . He is the rare type of doctor who forgets to make out his bills . He has a grizzled grey beard , and his hair is touched with grey . He wears silver-rimmed spectacles . His substantial but unpressed clothing is made by the village tailor .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good-morning , Andrew .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Good-morning , Doctor .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Casts a quick , professional glance at PETER .Peter , I 've come over to have a serious word with you . Been on my mind all night .Brings down a chair and sits opposite PETER .I — er — Frederik ...FREDERIK , who is not a favourite of the DOCTOR 'S , takes the hint and leaves the room .Peter , have you provided for everybody in this house ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What ? Have I —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: You 're a terrible man for planning , Peter ; but what have you done ?Casually .Were you to die ,— say to-morrow ,— how would it be with —Making a gesture to include the household .— the rest of them ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What do you mean ? If I were to die to-morrow ...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: You wo n't . Do n't worry . Good for a long time yet , but every one must come to it — sooner or later . I mean — what would Katie 's position be in this house ? I know you 've set your heart upon her marrying Frederik , and all that sort of nonsense , but will it work ? I 've always thought ‘ twas a pity Frederik was n't James and James was n't Frederik .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Oh , it 's all very well if she wants Frederik , but supposing she does not . Peter , if you mean to do something for her — do it now .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Now ? You mean that I — You mean that I might ... die ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: All can and do .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Studying the DOCTOR 'S face .You think ...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: The machinery is wearing out , Peter . Thought I should tell you . No cause for apprehension , but —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Then why tell me ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: When I cured you of that cold — wet flowerbeds — two days ago , I made a discovery .Seeing CATHERINE enter , he pauses . She is followed by MARTA , carrying a tray containing coffee and a plate of waffles .Coffee ! I told you not to touch coffee , Peter . It 's rank poison .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Would n't you like a cup , Doctor ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes he 'll take a cup . He wo n't prescribe it , but he 'll drink it .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Horrified .And hot waffles between meals !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , he 'll take hot waffles , too .MARTA goes to get another plate and more waffles , and CATHERINE follows her .Now , Andrew , you can n't tell me that I 'm sick . I wo n't have it . Every day we hear of some old boy one hundred years of age who was given up by the doctors at twenty . No , sir ! I 'm going to live to see children in my house ,— Katie 's babies creeping on my old floor ; playing with my old watch-dog , Toby . I 've promised myself a long line of rosy Grimms .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: My God , Peter ! That dog is fifteen years old now . Do you expect nothing to change in your house ? Man , you 're a home worshipper . However , I — I see no reason why —Lying .you should n't reach a ripe old age .Markedly , though feigning to treat the subject lightly .Er — Peter , I should like to make a compact with you ... that whoever does go first — and you 're quite likely to outlive me ,— is to come back and let the other fellow know ... and settle the question . Splendid test between old neighbours — real contribution to science .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Make a compact to — stuff and nonsense !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Do n't be too sure of that .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No , Andrew , no , positively , no . I refuse . Do n't count upon me for any assistance in your spook tests .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: CATHERINE has re-entered with another cup , saucer and plate which she sets on the table , and pours out the coffee .And how many times do you think you 've been a spook yourself ? You can n't tell me that man is perfect ; that he does n't live more than one life ; that the soul does n't go on and on . Pshaw ! The persistent personal energy must continue , or what is God ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Interested .Were you speaking of — of ghosts , Doctor ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , he has begun again .To CATHERINE .You 're just in time to hear it .To DR. MACPHERSON .Andrew , I 'll stay behind , contented in this life ; knowing what I have here on earth , and you shall die and return with your — ha !— persistent personal whatever-it-is , and keep the spook compact . Every time a knock sounds , or a chair squeaks , or the door bangs , I shall say , “ Sh ! There 's the Doctor ! ”

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Noticing a book which the DOCTOR has taken from his pocket , and reading the title .“ Are the Dead Alive ? ”

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Puts more sugar in his coffee .I 'm in earnest , Peter . I 'll promise and I want you to promise , too . Understand that I am not a so-called spiritist . I am merely a seeker after truth .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: That 's what they all are — seekers after truth . Rubbish ! Do you really believe such stuff ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: I know that the dead are alive . They 're here — here — near us — close at hand .PETER , in derision , lifts the table-cloth and peeps under the table — then , taking the lid off the sugar-bowl , peers into it .Some of the great scientists of the day are of the same opinion .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Bah ! Dreamers ! They accomplish nothing in the world . They waste their lives dreaming of the world to come .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: You can n't call Sir Charles Crookes , the inventor of Crookes Tubes ,— a waster ? Nor Sir Oliver Lodge , the great biologist ; nor Curie , the discoverer of radium ; nor Doctor Lombroso , the founder of Science of Criminology ; nor Doctors Maxwell , deVesmé , Richet , Professor James , of Harvard , and our own Professor Hyslop . Instead of laughing at ghosts , the scientific men of to-day are trying to lay hold of them . The frauds and cheats are being crowded from the field . Science is only just peeping through the half-opened door which was shut until a few years ago .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: If ever I see a ghost , I shall lay violent hands upon it and take it to the police station . That 's the proper place for frauds .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: I 'm sorry , Peter , very sorry , to see that you , like too many others , make a jest of the most important thing in life . Hyslop is right : man will spend millions to discover the North Pole , but not a penny to discover his immortal destiny .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Stubbornly .I do n't believe in spook mediums and never shall believe in them .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Probably most professional mediums cheat — perhaps every one of them ; but some of them are capable of real demonstrations at times .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Once a swindler , always a swindler . Besides , why can n't my old friends come straight back to me and say , “ Peter Grimm , here I am ! ” When they do — if they do — I shall be the first man to take off my hat to them and hold out my hand in welcome .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: You ask me why ? Why can n't a telegram travel on a fence instead of on a wire ? Your friends could come back to you if you could put yourself in a receptive condition ; but if you cannot , you must depend upon a medium — a sensitive .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: A what ?To CATHERINE .Something new , eh ? He has all the names for them . Yesterday it was “ apports ” — flowers that fell down from nowhere and hit you on the nose . He talks like a medium 's parrot . He has only to close his eyes and along comes the parade . Spooks ! Spooky spooks ! And now he wants me to settle my worldly affairs and join in the procession .

lg.l: Settle your worldly affairs ? What do you mean ,
Uncle Peter ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Evasively .Just some more of his nonsense . Doctor , you 've seen a good many cross to the other world ; tell me — did you ever see one of them come back — one ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Sipping his coffee .Never have , eh ? And never will . Take another cup of poison , Andrew . The DOCTOR gives his cup to CATHERINE , who fills it . PETER passes the waffles to the DOCTOR , at the same time winking at CATHERINE as the DOCTOR takes another .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: There was not perhaps the intimate bond between doctor and patients to bring them back . But in my own family , I have known of a case .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Apart to CATHERINE .He 's off again .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Eager to listen .Please do n't interrupt , Uncle . I love to hear him tell of —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: I have known of a return such as you mention . A distant cousin died in London and she was seen almost instantly in New York .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: She must have travelled on a biplane , Andrew .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: If my voice can be heard from San Francisco over the telephone , why cannot a soul with a God-given force behind it dart over the entire universe ? Is Thomas Edison greater than God ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Shocked .Doctor !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: And they can n't tuck it all on telepathy . Telepathy cannot explain the case of a spirit-message giving the contents of a sealed letter known only to the person that died . Here 's another interesting case .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: This is better than “ Puss in Boots , ” is n't it , Katie ? More — er — flibbertigibberty . Katie always loved fairy stories .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Listening eagerly .Uncle , please .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Ignoring PETER , speaking directly to CATHERINE , who is all attention .An officer on the Polar vessel , the Jeannette , sent to the Artic regions by the New York Herald , appeared at his wife 's bedside . She was in Brooklyn — he was on the Polar sea . He said to her , “ Count . ” She distinctly heard a ship 's bell and the word “ Count ” again . She had counted six when her husband 's voice said , “ Six bells — and the Jeanette is lost . ” The ship was really lost at the time she saw the vision .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: A bad dream . “ Six bells and the ” — Ha ! Ha ! Spirit messages ! Suet pudding has brought me messages from the North Pole , and I receive messages from Kingdom Come after I 've eaten a piece of mince pie .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: There have been seventeen thousand other cases found to be worth investigation by the London Society of Psychical Research .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Changing .Supposing , Andrew , that I did “ cross over ” — I believe that 's what you call dying ,— that I did want to come back to see how you and the little Katie and Frederik were getting on , how do you think I could manage to do it ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: When we hypnotize subjects , Peter , our thoughts take possession of them . As we enter their bodies , we take the place of a something that leaves them — a shadow-self . This self can be sent out of the room — even to a long distance . This self leaves us entirely after death on the first , second or third day , or so I believe . This is the force which you would employ to come back to earth — the astral envelope .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , but what proof have you , Doctor , that I 've got an — an astral envelope .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Easily .De Rochas has actually photographed it by radio-photography .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ha ! Ha ! Ha ! Ho ! Ho !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Mind you — they could n't see it when they photographed it .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I imagine not . See it ? Ho ! Ho !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: It stood a few feet away from the sleeper , and was located by striking at the air and watching for the corresponding portion of the sleeper 's body to recoil . By pricking a certain part of this shadow-self with a pin , the cheek of the patient could be made to bleed . The camera was focussed on this part of the shadow-self for fifteen minutes . The result was the profile of a head .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: After a pause .You believe that ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: The experiment has been repeated again and again . Nobody acquainted with the subject denies it now .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Turning away from the table as though he had heard enough .Spook pictures taken by professional mediums !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: De Rochas , who took the pictures of which I speak , is a lawyer of standing ; and the room was full of scientists who saw the pictures taken .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Hypnotized — all of them . Humbug , Andrew !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Under these conditions , it is quite impossible to hypnotize a room full of people . Perhaps you think the camera was hypnotized ? In similar circumstances , says Lombroso , an unnatural current of cold air went through the room and lowered the thermometer several degrees . Can you hypnotize a thermometer ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Impressed .That 's wonderful , Doctor !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , it 's a very pretty fairy story ; but it would sound better set to shivery music .Sings .Tol ! Dol ! Dol ! Dol !Rising to get his pipe and tobacco .No , sir ! I refuse to agree to your compact . You cannot pick the lock of heaven 's gate . We do n't come back . God did enough for us when he gave us life and strength to work and the work to do . He owes us no explanations . I believe in the old-fashioned paradise with a locked gate .He fills his pipe and lights it .No bogies for me .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Rising .Peter , I console myself with the thought that men have scoffed at the laws of gravitation , at vaccination , magnetism , daguerreotypes , steamboats , cars , telephones , wireless telegraphy and lighting by gas .Showing feeling .I 'm very much disappointed that you refuse my request .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Laying down his pipe on the table .Since you take it so seriously — here —Offers his hand .I 'll agree . I know you 're an old fool — and I 'm another . Now then —Shakes hands .it 's settled . Whichever one shall go first —He bursts into laughter — then controlling himself .If I do come back , I 'll apologize , Andrew .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Do you mean it ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I 'll apologize . WaitTaking the keys from the sideboard ., let us seal the compact in a glass of my famous plum brandy .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Good !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: As he passes off .We 'll drink to spooks .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: You really do believe , Doctor , that the dead can come back , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Of course I do , and why not ?

lg.l: Do you believe that you could come back here into this room and
I could see you ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: You might not see me ; but I could come back to this room .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Could you talk to me ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: And could I hear you ?

lg.stage: CATHERINE , still wondering , passes off with the tray . From the cellar , PETER can be heard singing lustily .
lg.l: I believe so . That 's what we 're trying to make possible .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: “ If you want a bite that 's good to eat ,Tra , la , ritte , ra , la , la , la !Try out a goose that 's fat and sweet ,Tra , la , ritte , ra , la , la , la ! ”During the song , MRS. BATHOLOMMEY has given a quick tap on the door and entered . She is about forty years of age . Her faded brown hair is streaked with grey . She wears a plain black alpaca costume .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Agitated .Good-morning , Doctor . Fortunate that I found you alone .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Dryly .Hy 're you , Mrs. Batholommey ?

div.stage: The REV . HENRY BATHOLOMMEY now enters . He is a man of about forty-five , wearing the frock coat , high waistcoat and square topped hat of a minister of the Dutch Reformed Church .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Hy 're , Henry ?

div.stage: The REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY bows . WILLIAM has returned from his errand and entered the room ,— a picture-book under his arm . He sits up by the window , absorbed in the pictures — unnoticed by the others .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Closing the door left open by PETER , shutting out the sound of his voice .Well , Doctor ...She pauses for a moment to catch her breath and wipe her eyes .I suppose you 've told him he 's got to die .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Eyeing MRS. BATHOLOMMEY with disfavour .Who 's got to die ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Why , Mr. Grimm , of course .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Amazed .Does the whole damned town know it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Easy , Doctor . You consulted Mr. Grimm 's lawyer and his wife told my wife .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: He gabbed , eh ? Hang the professional man who tells things to his wife .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Doctor !

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: With solicitude .Shakes his head .I greatly grieve to hear that Mr. Grimm has an incurable malady . His heart , I understand .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: He 's not to be told . Is that clear ? He may die in twenty minutes — may outlive us all — probably will .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Pointing to REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY .It seems to me , Doctor , that if you can n't do any more , it 's his turn . It 's a wonder you Doctors do n't baptize the babies .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Rose !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: At the last minute , he 'll want to make a will — and you know he has n't made one . He 'll want to remember the church and his charities and his friends ; and if he dies before he can carry out his intentions , the minister will be blamed as usual . It 's not fair .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Sh ! Sh ! My dear ! These private matters —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: I 'll trouble you , Mistress Batholommey , to attend to your own affairs . Did you never hear the story of the lady who flattened her nose — sticking it into other people 's business ?

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Doctor ! Doctor ! I can n't have that !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Let him talk , Henry . No one in this town pays any attention to Dr. MacPherson since he took up with spiritualism .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: He motions to her to be silent , as PETER , coming up the stairs from the cellar , is heard singing .Rose !

lg.l: “ Drop in the fat some apples red ,
lg.stage: Tra , la , ritte , ra , la , la , la !
lg.l: Then spread it on a piece of bread ,
lg.stage: Tra , la , ritte , ra , la , la , la !

div.stage: He opens the door , carrying a big bottle in his hand ; hailing the BATHOLOMMEYS cheerfully . ] Good-morning , good people . [ He puts the jug on the sideboard and hangs up the key . The BATHOLOMMEYS look sadly at PETER . MRS. BATHOLOMMEY in the fore-ground tries to smile pleasantly , but can only assume the peculiarly pained expression of a person about to break terrible news .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Rising to the occasion — warmly grasping PETER 'S hand .Ah , my dear friend ! Many thanks for the flowers William brought us , and the noble cheque you sent me . We 're still enjoying the vegetables you generously provided . I did relish the squash .

lg.stage: Catching a glimpse of MRS. BATHOLOMMEY 'S gloomy expression .
lg.l: Anything distressing you this morning , Mrs. Batholommey ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: No , no .... I hope you 're feeling well — er — I do n't mean that — I —

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Cheerily .Of course , she does ; and why not , why not , dear friend ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Will you have a glass of my plum brandy ?

lg.l: No , thank you . As you know , I belong to the
W. C. T. U .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Pastor ?

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY

lg.l: Of course . Why not ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Than I was ?

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Rose , my dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: William ? Why should you worry over William ? I am looking after him . I do n't understand —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Seeing that she has gone too far .I only meant — it 's too bad he had such an M —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: An M —?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY

F — was .
PETER . F —?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: In pantomime — as before .Father .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Oh ...Spelling out the word .S-c-o-u-n-d-r-e-l — whoever he is !Calls .William .WILLIAM looks up from his book .You 're very contented here with me , are you not ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: And you want to stay here ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Yes , sir .At that moment , a country circus band — playing a typical parade march — blares out as it comes up some distant street .There 's a circus in town .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: A circus ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Yes , sir . The parade has started .Opens the window and looks out towards left .Here it comes —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Hurrying to the door .Where ? Where ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Pointing .There !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: As delighted as WILLIAM .Gestures to the BATHOLOMMEYS to join him at the window . The music comes nearer and nearer — the parade is supposed to be passing . WILLIAM gives a cry of delight as a clown appears at the window with handbills under his arm .You 're right . It 's coming this way ! Here come the chariots .

sp.speaker: THE CLOWN
sp.p: As he throws the handbills into the room .Billy Miller 's big show and monster circus is in town this afternoon . Only one ring . No confusion .Seeing WILLIAM .Circus day comes but once a year , little sir . Come early and see the wild animals and hear the lions roar-r-r ! Mind !Holding up his finger to WILLIAM .I shall expect to see you . Wonderful troupe of trained mice in the side show .Sings .“ Uncle Rat has gone to town , Ha ! H 'm ! sp.p: My hat ? They laugh at my hat ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: We 'll have such a good time at the circus . It 's too bad you 've got to die , Mr. Grimm . There is a pause . PETER stops short , looking at WILLIAM . BATHOLOMMEY , whose smile has been frozen on her face , takes WILLIAM 'S hand and is about to draw him away , when PETER lays his hand on WILLIAM 'S shoulder . MRS. BATHOLOMMEY steps back .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Kindly .Yes , William , most people have to . ... What made you think of it just then ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Points to the DOCTOR .He said so . Perhaps in twenty minutes .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Quietly but very sternly .WILLIAM now understands that he should not have repeated what he heard .William !

sp.speaker: PETER

You heard the Doctor say that ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: His voice trembling .Y — es , sir .

sp.p: Looks round the room — beginning to understand .What did you mean , Andrew ?

sp.p: I 'll tell you , Peter , when we 're alone .

sp.p: But ...MRS. BATHOLOMMEY shakes her finger threateningly at WILLIAM who whimpers .WILLIAM goes for the tickets .Never mind . It popped out ; did n't it , William ? Get the circus tickets and we 'll have a fine time just the same .

sp.p: I — er — good-morning , dear friend .Takes PETER 'S hand .Any time you ‘ phone for me — day or night — I 'll run over instantly . God bless you , sir . I 've never come to you for any worthy charity and been turned away — never .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Suddenly overcomeIn tears , she follows her husband . The DOCTOR and PETER look at each other .Good-bye , Mr. Grimm .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Just a minute .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: TurningDo n't fret yourself , Peter . You 're not to imagine you 're worse than you are .Angrily .Do n't funk !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: CalmlyThat was n't my reason for detaining you , Andrew .With a twinkle in his eyeI merely wanted to say —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: PETER

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Thinking of his future in case of PETER 'S deathYes , sir .

When I 'm older ... When I 'm a little old leaf ready to curl up , eh , Fritz ?He drains the glass . sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Are you going ... after all ? ... And with that child ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Suddenly showing feeling .That little tattler ? A child that listens to everything and just told you ... He should n't be allowed in this part of the house . He should be sent away .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Astonished .Why do you dislike him , Frederik ? He 's a fine little fellow . You surprise me , my boy ...CATHERINE enters and goes to the piano , running her hands softly over the keys — playing no melody in particular . PETER thoughtfully takes one or two puffs ; then speaking so as not to be heard by CATHERINE .Frederik , I want to think that after I 'm gone , everything will be the same here ... just as it is now .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Sitting near PETER .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: FREDERIK nods assent . PETER smokes . The room is very cheerful . The bright midday sunshine creeps through the windows ,— almost causing a haze in the room — and resting on the pots and vases and bright flowers on the tables .Just as it is ...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Singing .“ The bird so free in the heavens ” —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Looking up — still in thought — seeming not to hear the song .FREDERIK nods assent .And my charities attended to .

lg.l: “ Is but the slave of the nest ;

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Who has been thinking .Just as though I were here .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: “ The rose must blow in the garden ” —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: William , too . Do n't forget him , Frederik .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: No , Uncle .

lg.l: “ The bee must gather its store ;
The cat must watch the mouse-hole ;
The dog must guard the door . ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: As though he had a weight off his mind .Smokes , listening with pleasure as CATHERINE finishes the song .We wo n't speak of this again . It 's understood .

lg.l: “ The cat must watch the mouse-hole ;
The dog must guard the door .
La la , La la , ” & c .
At the close of the song , PETER puts down his pipe and beckons to
CATHERINE .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: CATHERINE brings the Bible to PETER as the garden bell rings outside .Give me the Book .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Noon .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Opening the Book at the history of the family — points to the closely written page .Under my name I want to see this written : “ Married : Catherine and Frederik . ” I want to see you settled , Katie —Smilingsettled happily for life .He takes her hand and draws FREDERIK towards his chair . CATHERINE , embarrassed , plays with a rose in her belt .Will you ?...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE . I
sp.p: I do n't know ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Taking the rose and her hand in his ownI know for you , my dear . Make me happy .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: There 's nothing I would n't do to make you happy , Uncle , but —

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: You know that I love you , Kitty .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , yes , yes . That 's all understood . He has always loved you . Everybody knows it .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Uncle ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Slipping her hand in FREDERIK 'S , taking the rose , and tapping their clasped hands with the flower as he speaks .Make it a June wedding . We have ten days yet .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Say yes , Kitty .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: NervouslyI could n't in ten days ....

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: To FREDERIK .Who is arranging the marriage , you or I ? Say a month , then , Katie .... Promise me .

lg.l: If you have set your heart on it , I will ,
Uncle Peter ... I will ... I promise .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Takes a ring of his hand .The wedding ring — my dear mother 's .Gives it to CATHERINE .He kisses CATHERINE . Then , releasing her , he nods to FREDERIK to follow his example . PETER turns his back on the young people and smokes .You 've made me very happy , my dear .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Dreading his embrace , she retreats towards PETER and , as she touches him , his pipe falls to the floor . She looks at him , startled . FREDERIK , struck , looking intently at PETER who sits motionless .Catherine ...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Uncle Peter ... Uncle ! What is it ? What 's the matter ?Runs to the door — calling across the street .Doctor ! There he is — just going out .Calls .Come back . Come back , Doctor .To FREDERIK .I felt it . I felt something strange a minute ago . I felt it .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Taking PETER 'S hand .Uncle Peter !

lg.stage: Coming back to PETER and looking at him transfixed .
lg.l: Uncle
Peter ! Answer me ! ... It 's Katie !
The DOCTOR enters hurriedly .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: He goes quickly to PETER and listens to his heart . CATHERINE and FREDERIK on either side of him . The DOCTOR with tender sympathy takes CATHERINE in his arms .Is it ... Peter ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Rushes in with two tickets in his hand , leaving the door open . The circus music is faintly heard .Mr. Grimm !

lg.l: Sh !

lg.l: He 's gone .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Questioningly — dazed .CATHERINE is overcome .Dead ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: At PETER 'S side — holding up the circus ticket .He can n't be dead ... I 've got his ticket to the circus .

stage.stage: SCENE . The second act takes place ten days later , towards the close of a rainy afternoon . A fire is burning in the grate and a basket of hickory wood stands beside the hearth . PETER 'S hat is no longer on the peg . His pipes and jar of tobacco are missing . A number of wedding presents are set on a table , some unopened . The interior of the room , with its snapping fire , forms a pleasant contrast to the gloomy exterior . The day is fading into dusk . MRS. BATHOLOMMEY is at the piano , playing the wedding march from “ Lohengrin . ” Four little girls are grouped about her , singing the words to the air .
“ Faithful and true : We lead ye forth , Where love triumphant Shall lighten the way . ”
“ Bright star of love , Flower of the earth , Shine on ye both On Love 's perfect day . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: That 's better . Children , remember that this is to be a very quiet wedding . You 're to be here at noon to-morrow . You 're not to speak as you enter the room and take your places near the piano . Miss Staats will come down from her room ,— at least I suppose she will — and will stand ...Thinks .I do n't know where — but you 're to stop when I look at you . Watch me as though I were about to be married .She takes her place at the foot of the stairs and the children repeat the song until she has marched across the room and stationed herself in some appropriate corner . Hurry home between showers .The children go as she explains to FREDERIK .My Sunday-school scholars .... I thought your dear uncle would like a song at the wedding . sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: In a low voice .Where 's Catherine ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Taking up her fancy work , seating herself .Upstairs .

sp.p: With that sick child ? Tc !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Taking a telegram from his pocket-book .Well , we shall soon be off to Europe . I 've just had a telegram to say a cabin has been reserved for me on the Imperator . To-morrow , thank God , we shall take the afternoon train to New York .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I must confess that I 'm very glad . sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Sharply .I do n't understand you , Mrs. Batholommey .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I mean she seemed so averse to — to an immediate marriage ; but of course it was your uncle 's last request , and that influenced her more than anything else . I put them in the drawer —Points to desk .with the rest . It seems odd to think the postman brings your uncle 's letters regularly , yet he is not here .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Looking towards the door of the office .Did Hartman come ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Yes . He seemed rather surprised that you 'd sent for him .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Did you — er — tell him that we intend to leave to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I spoke of your wedding trip ,— yes .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Did he seem inclined to stay ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: He did n't say . He seemed very much agitated .MARTA enters , carrying a night lamp .We 'll pack Miss Catherine 's things to-night , Marta .She notices the lamp .The night lamp for William ?Looks up towards the door of his room .Go in very quietly . He 's asleep , I think .MARTA goes up the stairs and into WILLIAM 'S room .By the way , Mr. Batholommey was very much excited when he heard that your uncle had left a personal memorandum concerning us . We 're anxious to hear it read .FREDERIK , paying no attention to her words , is glancing at the wedding presents .We 're anxious to hear it read .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Entering .Did you wish to see me ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Offering his hand to JAMES .How do you do , Hartman ? I 'm very glad you consented to come back . My uncle never went into his office again after you left . There is some private correspondence concerning matters of which I know nothing ; it lies on your old desk .... I 'm anxious to settle everything to-night .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: BATHOLOMMEY leaves the room .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Very well . I have no doubt but that I can get through with it by midnight .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: If you care to remain longer with the firm , I — er —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , thank you .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I appreciate the fact that you came on my uncle 's account . I have no ill-feeling against you , Hartman .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 'm not refusing to stay because of any ill-feeling . I 'm going because I know that you 'll sell out before your uncle 's cold in his grave . I do n't care to stay to see the old place change hands .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I ? Sell out ? My intention is to carry out every wish of my dear old uncle 's .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Exit into the office .I hope so . I have n't forgotten that you wanted him to sell out to Hicks of Rochester on the very day he died . CATHERINE comes from WILLIAM 'S room , simply dressed in white — no touch of mourning . FREDERIK goes to the foot of the stairs and calls softly .

Imperator . Everything is arranged .

sp.p: Coming downstairs .Yes . ... I meant to speak to you — again .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: To-morrow 's the day , dear .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Very subdued .Yes ....

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: A June wedding — just as Uncle Peter wished .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: As before .Yes .... Just as he wished . Everything is just as he ....With a change of manner — earnestly — looking at FREDERIK .Frederik , I do n't want to go away . sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Why do you want to stay in this old cottage — with its candles and lamps and shadows ? It 's very gloomy , very depressing .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I do n't want to leave this house .... I do n't want any home but this .Panic-stricken .Do n't take me away Frederik . I know you 've never really liked it at Grimm 's Manor . Are you sure you 'll want to come back to live here ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: As though speaking to a child .Of course . I 'll do anything you ask .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I — I 've always wanted to please ...After a slight pause , finding it difficult to speak his name .Uncle Peter .... I felt that I owed everything to him .... sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I know ... I know .... It seems so disloyal to speak like this after I promised him ; but —

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Yes , you did promise Uncle Peter you 'd marry me , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: And he died believing you ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Then it all comes to this : are you going to live up to your promise ?

sp.p: That 's it . That 's what makes me try to live up to it .Wiping her eyes .But you know how I feel .... You understand ....

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Perfectly ; you do n't quite know your own mind .... Very few young girls do , I suppose . I love you and in time you 'll grow to care for me .MARTA re-enters from WILLIAM 'S room and closing the door comes down the stairs and passes off .What are we to do with that child ?

sp.p: He 's to stay here , of course .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: The child should be sent to some institution . What claim has he on you — on any of us ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Why do you dislike him ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I do n't , but —

sp.p: Yes , you do . I can n't understand it . I remember how angry you were when you came back from college and found him living here . sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: William is an uncomfortable child to have in the house . He has a way of staring at people as though he had a perpetual question on his lips . It 's most annoying .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: What question ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Nothing .... I was only thinking .... I was hoping that those we love ... and lose ... can n't see us here . I 'm beginning to believe there 's not much happiness in this world .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Why , you little snip . I 've a notion to spank you . Talking like that with life before you ! Read this book , child ;Gesturing towards the book on the sofa .it proves that the dead do see us ; they do come back .Walks to the foot of the stairs — turns .Catherine , I understand that you 've not a penny to your name — unless you marry Frederik ; that he has inherited you along with the orchids and tulips . It 's not too late .Goes half-way up the stairs — then pauses .Pointing to the wedding presents stand in the way of your future . [ Exit into WILLIAM 'S room . The rain increases . sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Uncle Peter ! Uncle Peter ! Why did you do it ? Why did you ask it ? Oh , dear ! Oh , dear ! If you could see me now .She stands rigid — her arms outstretched . MARTA , who has silently entered from the dining-room with fresh candles , goes to CATHERINE . sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: Others have troubles , too .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I had hoped , Marta , that Annamarie would have heard of Uncle 's loss and come back to us at this time ....

sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: If it had only brought us all together once more ; but no message ... nothing ... I cannot understand .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: She knows that our door is open .... The rain beats against the windows . A sharp double knock is heard at the door . CATHERINE starts as though suddenly brought to herself , hastily goes into the next room , taking the DOCTOR 'S book with her . MARTA has hurried towards the front door , when the REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY and COLONEL LAWTON appear in the hall as though they had entered quickly , to escape the storm . MARTA , greeting them , passes of to tell FREDERIK of their presence . The REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY wears a long , black cloth , rain-proof coat . COLONEL LAWTON wears a rubber poncho . COLONEL LAWTON is a tall man with a thin brown beard and moustache , about forty-eight . He is dressed in a Prince Albert coat , unpressed trousers , and a negligée shirt . He wears spectacles and has a way of throwing back his head and peering at people before answering them . The REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY sets his umbrella in the hall and the COLONEL hangs his broad-brimmed hat on the handle — as though to let it drip .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Brr ! I believe it 's raining icicles .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Taking off his overshoes .Gee Whillikins ! What a day ! Good thing the old windmill out yonder is tied up . Great weather for baptisms , Parson .There is a faint , far-away rumble of thunder . FREDERIK enters .Well , here we are , Frederik , my boy — at the time you mentioned .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: How are you , Frederik ? COLONEL LAWTON crosses to the fire , followed by the REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Who has gone to the desk for a paper lying under a paper-weight .There is a louder peal of thunder . A flash of lightning illuminates the room .I sent for you to hear a memorandum left by my uncle . I only came across it yesterday .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: I must have drawn up ten wills for the old gentleman , but he always tore ‘ em up . May I have a drink of his plum brandy , Frederik ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Help yourself . Pastor ?

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Er — er — COLONEL LAWTON goes to the sideboard and pours out two drinks from a decanter . A heavy roll of thunder now ends in a sharp thunderclap . MRS. BATHOLOMMEY , who is entering the room , gives a cry and puts her hands over her face . COLONEL LAWTON bolts his whiskey . The REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY takes a glass and stands with it in his hand .

lg.stage: Removing her hands in time to see the brandy .
lg.l: Why ,
Henry ! What are you doing ? Are your feet wet ?

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Drinks .No , Rose ; they 're not . I want a drink and I 'm going to take it . It 's a bad night .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Throws a hickory log on the fire , which presently blazes up , making the room much lighter .Sits .Go ahead , Frederik .

sp.speaker: REV . MR
sp.p: BATHOLOMMEY has drawn up a chair for his wife , and now seats himself before the snapping hickory fire .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I knew that your uncle would remember his friends and his charities . He was so liberal ! One might say of him that he was the very soul of generosity . He gave in such a free-handed , princely fashion .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Reading in a businesslike manner .For Mrs. Batholommey —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: The dear man — to think that he remembered me ! I knew he 'd remember the church and Mr. Batholommey , of course ; but to think that he 'd remember me ! He knew that my income was very limited . He was so thoughtful ! His purse was always open .

lg.stage: Eyes MRS. BATHOLOMMEY for a second , then continues .
lg.l: For
Mr. Batholommey —
and the Colonel .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Taking out a cigar .He knew that I did the best I could for him ...His voice breaks .the grand old man .Recovering .Nods inquiringly at MRS. BATHOLOMMEY , who bows assent , and he lights his cigar .What 'd he leave me ? Mrs . B .— er ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Glancing at the paper .Mrs. Batholommey , he wished you to have his miniature — with his affectionate regards .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Dear old gentleman — and er — yes ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: To Mr. Batholommey —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: But — er — you did n't finish with me .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: You 're finished .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I 'm finished ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: You may read it yourself if you like .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: No , no , no . She 'll take your word for it .Firmly .Rose !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Reads .“ To Mr. Batholommey , my antique watch fob — with my profound respects . ”Continues .To Colonel Lawton —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: His watch fob ? Is that what he left to Henry ? Is that all ?As FREDERIK nods .Well ! If he had no wish to make your life easier , Henry , he should at least have left something for the church . Oh ! Wo n't the congregation have a crow to pick with you !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Reading .COLONEL LAWTON has a look on his face as though he were saying , “ Ah ! I 'll get something worth while . ”“ To my life-long friend , Colonel Lawton , I leave my most cherished possession . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Angrily .When the church members hear that —

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Chewing his cigar .I do n't know why he was called upon to leave anything to the church — he gave it thousands ; and only last month , he put in chimes . As I look at it , he wished to give you something he had used — something personal . Perhaps the miniature and the fob ai n't worth three whoops in Hell ,— it 's the sentiment of the thing that counts —Chewing the word with his cigar .the sentiment . Drive on , Fred .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: “ To Colonel Lawton , my father 's prayer-book . ”

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Suddenly changing — dazed .His prayer-book ... me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Seeing FREDERIK lay down the paper and rise .Is that all ?
