sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: That 's all .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Still dazed .A prayer-book .... Me ? Well , I 'll be —Struck .Here , Parson , let 's swap . You take the prayer-book — I 'll take the old fob .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Stiffly .Goes to the window and looks out — his back turned to the others — trying to control his feelings .Thank you . I already have a prayer-book .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Her voice trembling with vexation and disappointment .Well , all that I can say is — I 'm disappointed in your uncle .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Is it for this you hauled us out in the rain , Frederik ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Bitterly .I see now ... he only gave to the church to show off .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Rose ! ... I myself am disappointed , but —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: He did ! Or why did n't he continue his work ? He was not a generous man . He was a hard , uncharitable , selfish old man .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Horrified .Rose , my dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: He was ! If he were here , I 'd say it to his face . The congregation sicked you after him . Now that he 's gone and you 'll get nothing more , they 'll call you slow — slow and pokey . You 'll see ! You 'll see to-morrow .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Sh !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: As for the Colonel , who spent half his time with Mr. Grimm , what is his reward ? A watch-fob !Prophetically .Henry , mark my words — this will be the end of you . It 's only a question of a few weeks . One of these new football playing ministers , just out of college , will take your place . It 's not what you preach now that counts ; it 's what you coax out of the rich parishioners ’ pockets .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: In a low voice .Mrs. Batholommey !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Religion does n't stand where it did , Henry — there 's no denying that . There was a time when people had to go to church — they were n't decent if they did n't . Now you have to wheedle ‘ em in . The church needs funds in these days when a college professor is openly saying that —Her voice breaks .Weeps .the Star of Bethlehem was a comet .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Control yourself . I must insist upon it , Mrs. Batholommey .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Breaking down — almost breathlessly .Oh ! If I said all the things I feel like saying about Peter Grimm — well — I should n't be fit to be a clergyman 's wife . Not to leave his dear friends a —

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: COLONEL LAWTON stirs the fire — a log falls out and the flame goes down . The room has gradually grown darker as the night approaches .He was n't liberal ; but , for God 's sake , madam , pull yourself together and think what he ought to have done for me !— I 've listened to his plans for twenty years . I 've virtually given up my business for him , and what have I got out of it ? Not a button ! Not a button ! A bible . Still I 'm not complaining . Hang that chimney , Frederik , it 's smoking .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Turning on COLONEL LAWTON .Oh , you 've feathered your nest , Colonel ! You 're a rich man .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Enraged , raising his voice .What ? I never came here that you were n't begging .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Virtuously — laying down the paper .Well , I 'm disgusted ! When I think how much more I should have if he had n't continually doled out money to every one of you !

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: He was putty in your hands .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Yes , you can afford to defend his memory — you 've got the money .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I do n't defend his memory . He was a gullible old fossil , and the whole town knew it .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: You did at any rate . I 've heard you flatter him by the hour .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Of course . He liked flattery and I gave him what he wanted . Why not ? I gave him plenty . The rest of you were at the same thing ; and I had the pleasure of watching him give you the money that belonged to me — to me — my money .... What business had he to be generous with my money ?The COLONEL strikes a match to light his cigar , and , as it flares up , the face of FREDERIK is seen — distorted with anger .He pauses , knowing that he has said too much . The room is now very dark . The rain has subsided . Everything is quiet outside . There is not a sound , save the ticking of the clock .I 'll tell you this : had he lived much longer , there would have been nothing left for me . It 's a fortunate thing for me that —

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Solemnly — breaking the pause .Young man , it might have been better had Mr. Grimm given his all to charity — for he has left his money to an ingrate .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Laughing derisively .Ha ! Ha !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Sh ! Someone 's coming . All is quiet . The clock ticks in the dark . The door opens .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: With a change of voice .Come in .Nobody enters .A pause . He strikes a match and holds it above his head . The light shows the open door . A wind , blowing through the doorway , causes the match to flicker , and FREDERIK protects it with his hand .Where 's a light ? We 've been sitting in the dark like owls . Come in .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: I 'll see who 's ...Looks out .No one .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Someone must be there . Who opened the door ?The wind puts out the match in FREDERIK 'S hand . The room is once more in semi-darkness .FREDERIK strikes another match and holds it up . The door is seen to be closed .There ... it closed again ...

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Who is nearest to the door .I did n't touch it .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Blowing out the match .I 'll have the lamps brought in .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Curious ...

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: It was the wind — a draught .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Returning to his chair .Must have been .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Entering with a lamp .Did someone call me ? Without pausing , she sets the lamp on the table down right — opposite the group of characters . She turns up the wick and PETER GRIMM is seen standing in the room — half in shadow . He is as he was in life . The clothes he wears appear to be those he wore about his house in the first act . He carries his hat in his hand . He has the same kind smile , the same deferential manner , but his face is more spiritual and years younger . The lamp , which CATHERINE has placed on the table , brightens the room .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Whose eyes never leave CATHERINE .Yes ... I called you .... I 've come back .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: To CATHERINE .No .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Do n't be frightened , Katie . It 's the most natural thing in the world . You wanted me and I came .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Why ? What made you think someone called you ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I 'm so accustomed to hear Uncle Peter 's voice in this room , that sometimes I forget he 's not here ... I can n't get over it ! I was almost sure I heard him speak ... but , of course , as soon as I came in — I remembered .... But some one must have called me .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: No . PETER stands looking at them , perplexed ; not being able to comprehend as yet that he is not seen .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Is n't it curious ... to hear your name and turn and ...Unconsciously , she looks in PETER 'S face .no one there ?

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Kindly .Nerves ... imagination .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: You need a complete change .Crossing to the door .For heaven 's sake , let 's have more light or we shall all be hearing voices .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: His eyes have followed CATHERINE who is now at the door .Strange .... Nobody seems to see me .... It 's — it 's extraordinary ! Katie ! ... Katie ! ...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Pausing .Perhaps it was the book I was reading that made me think I heard .... The Doctor lent it to me .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Pooh-poohing .Oh !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Half to herself .She passes out of the room .If he does know , if he can see , he 'll be comforted by the thought that I 'm going to do everything he wanted .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Showing that he does not want her to carry out his wishes .No , no , do n't ... Frederik , I want to speak to you .

div.stage: FREDERIK , not glancing in PETER 'S direction , lights a cigarette .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Well , Frederik , I hope the old gentleman can see his mistake now .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I can see several mistakes .REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY rises and goes towards the door , pausing in front of PETER to take out his watch .Mr. Batholommey , I 'm glad to see you in my house .... I 'm very sorry that you can n't see me . I was n't pleased with my funeral sermon ; it was very gloomy — very . I never was so depressed in my life .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: To FREDERIK .Do you know what I should like to say to your uncle ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I hope at least you 'll care for the parish poor as your uncle did — and keep on with some of his charities .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Putting his hand on REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY 'S shoulder .That 's all attended to . I arranged all that with Frederik . He must look after my charities .

lg.l: I might as well tell you now — you need n't look to me . It 's Uncle
Peter 's fault if your charities are cut off .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Half-doubtingly .It does n't seem possible that he made no arrangements to continue his good works .FREDERIK remains stolid . REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY puts back his watch after glancing at it .Goes into the hall to put on his overshoes , coat , & c ., leaving PETER 'S hand extended in the air .Just thirty minutes to make a call .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Rising .I must be toddling .Pauses .He stands , thinking matters over — cigar in mouth , his hand on his chin .It 's queer , Frederik , how things turn out in this world .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Slipping his hand through COLONEL LAWTON 'S arm . They seem to look each other in the eye .You were perfectly right about it , Thomas , I should have made a will ... I — suppose it is a little too late , is n't it ?... It would be — er — unusual to do it now , would n't it ? COLONEL LAWTON , who has heard nothing — seen nothing — moves away as though PETER had never held his arm , and goes up into the hall for his cape and overshoes .

lg.stage: Noticing an old gold-headed walking-stick in the hall .
lg.l: Oh , er — what are you going to do with all the old man 's family relics ,
Frederik ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: The junk , you mean ? I shall lay it on some scrap-heap , I suppose . It 's not worth a penny .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: I 'm not so sure of that . They say there 's a lot of money paid for this sort of trash .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Is that so ? Not a bad idea to have a dealer in to look it over . PETER stands listening , a faint smile on his face .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: If I could have the old clock — cheap , Frederik , I 'd take it off your hands .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Sets his watch by the clock . MRS. BATHOLOMMEY gives him a look and joins her husband at the door .I 'll find out how much it 's worth . I shall have everything appraised .

sp.speaker: COLONEL LAWTON
sp.p: Exit , closing the door .Good-night .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: As REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY goes out — calling after him .MRS. BATHOLOMMEY leaves the room too disgusted for words . FREDERIK goes into the office .Henry , Catherine wants you to come back for supper .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Now alone .We live and learn ... and oh ! what I have learned since I came back ....He goes to his own particular peg in the vestibule and hangs up his hat . He glances at the wedding presents . Presently he sees the flowers which CATHERINE has placed on the desk . With a smile , he touches the flowers . MARTA enters with another lamp , which she places on a table . As PETER 'S eyes rest on MARTA , he nods and smiles in recognition , waiting for a response .Well , Marta ?... Do n't you know your old master ?... No ?... No ?...She winds the clock and leaves the room .I seem to be a stranger in my own house ... yet the watch-dog knew me and wagged his tail as I came in .He stands trying to comprehend it all .Well ! Well !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Looking at his watch , re-enters from the office and goes to the ‘ phone , which presently rings . FREDERIK instantly lifts the receiver as though not wishing to attract attention . In a low voice .Yes ... I was waiting for you . How are you , Mr. Hicks ?Listens .I 'm not anxious to sell — no . I prefer to carry out my dear old uncle 's wishes .PETER eyes him — a faint smile on his lips .If I got my price ? Well ... of course in that case ... I might be tempted . To-morrow ? No , I can n't see you to-morrow . I 'm going to be married to-morrow , and leave at once for New York . Thank you .Listens .To-night ? Very well , but I do n't want it known . I 'll sell , but it must be for more than the price my uncle refused . Make it ten thousand more and it 's done .Listens .You 'll come to-night ?... Yes , yes ....Listens at the ‘ phone .The dear old man told you his plans never failed , eh ? God rest his soul !Laughing indulgently .Ha ! Ha ! Ha !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ha ! Ha ! Ha !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Echoing HICKS ’ words .What would he say if he knew ? What could he say ? Everything must change . A far-away rumble of thunder is heard — the lightning flickers at the window and a flash is seen on the telephone which tinkles and responds as though from the electric shock . Exclaiming “ Ugh , ” FREDERIK drops the receiver — which hangs down .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: The storm passes as he speaks into the receiver without touching the telephone .Good-evening , my friend . We shall soon meet — face to face . You wo n't be able to carry this matter through ....Looking into space as though he could see the future .You 're not well and you 're going out to supper to-night ; ... you will eat something that will cause you to pass over .... I shall see you to-morrow .... A happy crossing !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Picks up the receiver .Hello ?... You do n't feel well , you say ?Then echoing the purport of HICKS ’ answer .I see .... Your lawyer can attend to everything to-night without you . Very well . It 's entirely a question of money , Mr. Hicks . Send your lawyer to the Grimm Manor Hotel . I 'll arrange at once for a room . Good-bye .Hangs up the receiver .He lights a fresh cigarette — his face expressing the satisfaction he feels in the prospect of a perfectly idle future . PETER looks at him as though to say : “ And that 's the boy whom I loved and trusted ! ” FREDERIK gets his hat , throws his coat over his arm , and hastens out .That 's off my mind .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Turns and faces the door leading into the next room , as though he could feel the presence of some one waiting there .Yes ... I am still in the house . Come in ... come in ...He repeats the signal of the first act .Ou — oo .The door opens slowly — and CATHERINE enters as though at PETER 'S call . She looks about her , not understanding . He holds out his arms to her . CATHERINE walks slowly towards him . He takes her in his arms , but she does not respond . She does not know that she is being held .There ! There !... Do n't worry .... It 's all right .... We 'll arrange things very differently . I 've come back to change all my plans .She moves away a step — just out of his embrace . He tries to call her back .She moves about the room in thought . As PETER watches her — she pauses near his desk .Katie ! ... Ca n't I make my presence known to you ? Katie ! Ca n't my love for you outlive me ? Is n't it here in the home ?... Do n't cry .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Suddenly .Crying does n't help matters .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: She hears me . She does n't know it , but she hears me . She 's cheering up .She inhales the flowers — a half smile on her lips .Suddenly giving way to the realization of her loss , CATHERINE sighs .That 's right , you have n't smiled before since I died .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Correcting himself .I — I mean — since I learned that there was a happier place than the world I left .... I 'm a trifle confused . I 've not had time to adjust myself to these new conditions .CATHERINE smiles sadly — goes up to the window , and , leaning against the pane , looks out into the night . PETER continues comfortingly .The dead have never really died , you know . We could n't die if we tried . We 're all about you .... Look at the gardens : they 've died , have n't they ? But there they are all the better for it . Death is the greatest thing in the world . It 's really a — Ha !— delightful experience . What is it , after all ? A nap from which we waken rested , refreshened ... a sleep from which we spring up like children tumbling out of bed — ready to frolic through another world . I was an old man a few days ago ; now I 'm a boy . I feel much younger than you — much younger .A conflict is going on in CATHERINE 'S mind . She walks to the chair by the fireplace and sits — her back to the audience . He approaches her and lays a tender hand on her shoulder .I know what you 're thinking .... Katie , I want you to break that very foolish promise I asked you to make . You 're almost tempted to . Break it ! Break it at once ; then —Glancing smilingly towards the door through which he came — as though he wished to leave — like a child longing to go back to play .then I could — take the journey back in peace .... I can n't go until you do — and I ... I long to go .... Is n't my message any clearer to you ?Reading her mind .You have a feeling ... an impression of what I 'm saying ; but the words ... the words are not clear .... Mm ... let me see .... If you can n't understand me — there 's the Doctor , he 'll know how to get the message — he 'll find the way .... Then I can hurry back ... home ....

lg.stage: Helplessly — changing her position like a tired child .
lg.l: Oh ,
I 'm so alone .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Cheerily .Not alone at all — not at all . I shall drop in very often ... and then , there 's your mother .Suddenly remembering .Oh , yes , I had almost forgotten . I have a message for you , Katie ....He seats himself in a chair which is almost in front of her .I 've met your mother .She sits in a reverie . PETER continues with the air of a returned traveller relating his experiences .She heard that I had crossed over and there she was — waiting for me . You 're thinking of it , are n't you ? Wondering if we met .... Yes , that was the first interesting experience . She knew me at once . “ You were Peter Grimm , ” she said , “ before you knew better ” — that 's what they call leaving this world — “ to know better . ” You call it “ dying . ”Confidentially .She 's been here often , it seems , watching over you . I told her how much I loved you and said that you had a happy home . I spoke of your future — of my plans for you and Frederik . “ Peter Grimm , ” she said , “ you 've over-looked the most important thing in the world — love . You have n't given her her right to the choice of her lover — her right ! ” Then it came over me that I 'd made a terrible mistake ... and at that minute , you called to me .Impressively .In the darkness surrounding all I had left behind , there came a light ... a glimmer where you stood ... a clear call in the night .... It seemed as though I had not been away one second ... but in that second , you had suffered .... Now I am back to show you the way .... I am here to put my hand on your dear head and give you your mother 's blessing ; to say she will be with you in spirit until she holds you in her arms — you and your loved husband —CATHERINE turns in her chair and looks towards the door of the room in which JAMES is working . PETER catches the thought .— yes , James , it 's you .... And the message ended in this kiss .Prints a kiss on her cheek .Ca n't you think I 'm with you , dear child ? Ca n't you think I 'm trying to help you ? Ca n't you even hope ? Oh , come , at least hope ! Anybody can hope . CATHERINE rises with an entire change of manner — takes a bright red blossom from the vase on PETER 'S desk — then deliberately walks to the door of the room in which JAMES is working . PETER follows her action hopefully . She does not tap on the door , however , but turns and sits at the piano — in thought — not facing the piano . She puts PETER 'S flowers against her face . Then , laying the flowers on the piano , sings softly three or four bars of the song she sang in the first act — and stops abruptly .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: To herself .That I should sit here singing — at a time like this !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Sing ! Sing ! Why not ? Lift up your voice like a bird ! Your old uncle does n't sleep out there in the dust . That 's only the dream . He 's here — here — alive . All his age gone and youth glowing in his heart . If I could only tell you what lies before you — before us all ! If people even suspected what the next life really is , they would n't waste time here — I can tell you that . They 'd do dreadful things to get away from this existence — make for the nearest pond or —Pausing abruptly .Ah , here comes someone who 'll know all about it !The DOCTOR comes from WILLIAM 'S room . PETER greets him in a cordial but casual way , as though he had parted from him only an hour before .Well , Andrew , I apologize .Bowing obsequiously .You were right . I apologize .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: How is he , Doctor ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: William is better . Dropped off to sleep again . Ca n't quite understand him .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I apologize . I said that if I could come back , I would ; and here I am — apologizing . Andrew ! Andrew !Trying to attract DR. MACPHERSON 'S attention .I have a message , but I can n't get it across . This is your chance . I want you to take it . I do n't wish Catherine to marry Frederik .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: He 's somewhat feverish yet .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ca n't you understand one word ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: It 's a puzzling case ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: What ? Mine ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Getting a pad from his pocket — writing out a prescription with his fountain pen .I 'll leave this prescription at the druggist 's —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I 'm quite shut out .... They 've closed the door and turned the key on me .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Suddenly noticing that CATHERINE seems more cheerful .What 's happened ? I left you in tears and here you are — all smiles .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Yes , I — I am happier — for some reason .... For the last few minutes I — I 've had such a strange feeling .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: That 's odd : so have I ! Been as restless as a hungry mouse . Something seemed to draw me down here — can n't explain it .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I 'm beginning to be felt in this house .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Sitting at the table .Catherine , I have the firm conviction that , in a very short time , I shall hear from Peter .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I hope so . It 's high time now .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Thinks .What I want is some positive proof ; some absolute test ; some — er — CATHERINE has seated herself at the table .— Unconsciously they both occupy the same seats as in the first act .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: The trouble is with other people , not with us . You want us to give all sorts of proofs ; and here we are just back for a little while — very poorly put together on the chance that you 'll see us at all .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Poor old Peter — bless his heart !His elbow on the table as though he had been thinking over the matter . CATHERINE sits quietly listening .If he kept that compact with me , and came back ,— do you know what I 'd ask him first ? If our work goes on .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well , now , that 's a regular sticker . It 's bothered me considerably since I crossed over .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: What do you mean , Doctor ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: The question every man wants the answer to : what 's to become of me — me — my work ? Am I going to be a bone setter in the next life and he a tulip man ?... I wonder .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Andrew , I 've asked everybody — Tom , Dick and Harry . One spirit told me that sometimes our work does go on ; but he was an awful liar — you knew we do n't drop our earth habits at once . He said that a genius is simply a fellow who 's been there before in some other world and knows his business . Now then :Confidentially preparing to open an argument — sitting in his old seat at the table , as in the first act .it stands to reason , Andrew , does n't it ? What chance has the beginner compared with a fellow who knew his business before he was born ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Unconsciously grasping the thought .I believe it is possible to have more than one chance at our work .

lg.l: There ... you caught that .... Why can n't you take my message to
Catherine ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Rising to get his shawl — gruffly .Thought over what I told you concerning this marriage ? Not too late to back out .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: He 's beginning to take the message .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Everything 's arranged : I shall be married as Uncle Peter wished . I sha'n ' t change my mind .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Picks up his shawl .H 'm !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Trying to detain the DOCTOR — tugging at his shawl without seeming to pull it .Do n't give up ! Do n't give up ! A girl can always change her mind — while there 's life . Do n't give up !The DOCTOR turns , facing PETER , looking directly at him as he puts his hand in his coat pocket .You heard that , eh ?... Did n't you ? Yes ? Did it cross over ?... What ?... It did ?... You 're looking me in the face , Andrew ; can you see me ?The DOCTOR takes a pencil out of his pocket , writes a prescription , throws his shawl over his shoulder — turning his back towards PETER and facing CATHERINE .Tc ! Tc ! Tc !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Good-night .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: CATHERINE goes quietly to the fireplace , kneeling down , mends the fire , and remains there sitting on an ottoman .Good-night .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Calling after the DOCTOR .If I could only make some sign — to start you thinking ; but I can n't depend upon you , I see that ....Then changing — as though he had an idea .Ah , yes ! There is another way . Now to work .With renewed activity , he taps in the direction of the office door , although he himself stands three feet away from it . The door opens promptly and JAMES appears on the threshold — pen in hand — as though something had made him rise suddenly from his desk . CATHERINE , still seated , does not see JAMES , who stands looking at her — remembering that she is to be married on the following day . PETER tempts JAMES .Yes , she is pretty , James ... young and lovely .... Look !... There are kisses tangled in her hair where it curls ... hundreds of them .... Are you going to let her go ? Her lips are red with the red of youth . Every smile is an invocation to life . Who could resist her smiles ? Can you , James ? No , you will not let her go . And her hands , James .... Look ! Hands made to clasp and cling to yours . Imagine her little feet trudging happily about your home .... Look at her shoulders ... shaped for a resting-place for a little head .... You were right , James , we should ask nothing of our girls but to marry the men they love and be happy wives and happy mothers of happy children . You feel what I am saying .... You could n't live without her , could you ? No ? Very well , then —Changing abruptly .Now , it 's your turn . JAMES pauses a moment . There is silence . Then he comes forward a step and CATHERINE , hearing him , turns and rises .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Coldly — respectfully .Miss Grimm ...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: James ...

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I felt that you were here and wished to speak to me . I — I do n't know why ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good for James .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Shaking hands with him .I 'm very glad to see you again , James .When PETER sees that he has brought the two young people together , he stands in the background . The lovers are in the shadow , but PETER 'S figure is marked and clear .Why did you go away ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Oh — er —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: And without saying a word .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Your uncle sent me away . I told him the truth again .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Oh ...

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I am going in a few hours .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Where are you going ? What do you intend to do ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Half-heartedly .Father and I are going to try our luck together . We 're going to start with a small fruit farm . It will give me a chance to experiment ....

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Her voice trembling .It will seem very strange when I come back home .... Uncle gone ... and you , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I hope you 'll be happy , Catherine .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: James , Uncle died smiling at me — thinking of me ... and just before he went , he gave me his mother 's wedding ring and asked me to marry Frederik . I shall never forget how happy he was when I promised . That was all he wanted . His last smile was for me ... and there he sat — still smiling after he was gone ... the smile of a man leaving the world perfectly satisfied — at peace . It 's like a hand on my heart — hurting it — when I question anything he wanted . I could n't meet him in the hereafter if I did n't do everything he wished ; I could n't say my prayers at night ; I could n't speak his name in them .... He trusted me ; depended upon me ; did everything for me ; so I must do this for him .... I wanted you to know this , James , because ...

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Why have n't you told Frederik the truth ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I have .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: That you do n't love him ?CATHERINE does n't answer , but JAMES knows .And he 's willing to take you like that ?— a little girl like you — in that way .... God ! He 's rotten all the way through . He 's even worse than I thought . Katie , I did n't mean to say a word of this to-day — not a word ; but a moment since — something made me change my mind — I do n't know what !...PETER smiles .I felt that I must talk to you . You looked so young , so helpless , such a child . You 've never had to think for yourself — you do n't know what you 're doing . You could n't live under it , Catherine . You 're making the greatest mistake possible , if you marry where you do n't love . Why should you carry out your uncle 's plans ? You 're going to be wretched for life to please a dead man who does n't know it ; or , if he does know it , regrets it bitterly .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I agree with you now , James .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: You mus n't say that , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: But I will say it — I will speak my mind . I do n't care how fond you were of your uncle or how much he did for you — it was n't right to ask this of you . It was n't fair . The whole thing is the mistake of a very obstinate old man .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: James !

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I loved him , too ; but he was an obstinate old man . Sometimes I think it was the Dutch blood in his veins .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: A very frank , outspoken fellow . I like to hear him talk — now .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Do you know why I was sent away ? Why I quarrelled with your uncle ? I said that I loved you ... he asked me .... I did n't tell him because I had any hopes — I had n't .... I have n't now ....Struck .But in spite of what I 'm saying ... I do n't know what makes me think that I ... I could take you in my arms and you would let me ... but I do think it .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Retreats , backing towards PETER .No !... Do n't touch me , James — you must n't ! Do n't !... Do n't ! PETER pushes her into JAMES ’ arms , without touching her . She exclaims “ Oh , James ! ” and fairly runs towards JAMES as though violently propelled . In reality , she thinks that she is yielding to an impulse . As she reaches him , she exclaims “ No , ” and turns back , but JAMES , with outstretched arms , catches her .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Draws her to him .You love me .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Do n't make me say that , James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I will make you say it ! You do love me .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: No matter if I do , that wo n't alter matters .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: What ? What ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: No , no , do n't say any more .... I wo n't hear it .She stands free of JAMES — then turns and walks to the stairs .Good-bye , Jim .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Do you mean it ? Are you really going to sacrifice yourself because of — Am I really losing you ?... Catherine ! Catherine !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: In tears — beseechingly .Please do n't .... Please do n't ....

div.stage: FREDERIK enters . Until the entrance of FREDERIK , PETER has had hope in his face , but now he begins to feel apprehensive .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Throwing his hat and coat on a chair .I have some work to do — more of my uncle 's unopened mail ; then I 'll join you , Hartman . We must — er — make haste . JAMES looks at CATHERINE , then at FREDERIK . CATHERINE gives him an imploring glance — urging him not to speak . FREDERIK has gone to PETER 'S desk .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Goes towards the hall .I 'll come back later .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Catherine , have you asked James to be present at the ceremony to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: James , will you —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I shall be leaving early in the morning .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Exit JAMES .Too bad ! FREDERIK lights the desk candles , takes the mail out of the drawer — opens two letters — tears them up after barely glancing at them — then sees CATHERINE still standing at the foot of the stairs — her back to him . He lays the cigar on the desk , crosses , and , taking her in his arms , kisses her .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: With a revulsion of feeling .No ! No ! No !She covers her face with her hands — trying to control herself .Please !... Not now ....

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Why not now ?Suspiciously .Has Hartman been talking to you ? What has he been saying to you ?CATHERINE starts slowly up the stairs .Wait a moment , please ....As she retreats a step up the stairs , he follows her .Do you really imagine you — you care for that fellow ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Do n't — please .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: I 'm sorry to insist . Of course , I knew there was a sort of school-girl attachment on your part ; ... that you 'd known each other since childhood . I do n't take it at all seriously . In three months , you 'll forget him . I must insist , however , that you do not speak to him again to-night . After to-morrow — after we are married — I 'm quite sure that you will not forget you are my wife , Catherine — my wife .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: She escapes into her room . FREDERIK goes to his desk .I sha'n ' t forget .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Confronting FREDERIK .Now , sir , I have something to say to you , Frederik Grimm , my beloved nephew ! I had to die to find you out ; but I know you !FREDERIK is reading a letter .You sit there opening a dead man 's mail — with the heart of a stone — thinking : “ He 's gone ! he 's gone !— so I 'll break every promise ! ” But there is something you have forgotten — something that always finds us out : the law of reward and punishment . Even now it is overtaking you . Your hour has struck .FREDERIK takes up another letter and begins to read it ; then , as though disturbed by a passing thought , he puts it down . As though perplexed by the condition of his own mind , he ponders , his eyes resting unconsciously on PETER .Your hour has struck .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: To himself .What in the world is the matter with me to-night ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Read !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Has opened a long , narrow , blue envelope containing a letter on blue paper and a small photograph . He stares at the letter , aghast .My God ! Here 's luck .... Here 's luck ! From that girl Annamarie to my uncle . Oh , if he had read it !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Standing in front of FREDERIK looks into space — as though reading the letter in the air .“ Dear Mr. Grimm : I have not written because I can n't do anything to help William , and I am ashamed . ”

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Wh !As though he had read the first part to himself , now reads aloud .Hesitates .“ Do n't be too hard upon me .... I have gone hungry trying to save a few pennies for him , but I never could ; and now I see that I cannot hope to have him back . William is far better off with you . I — ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Going back of the desk , standing behind FREDERIK 'S chair .Go on ....

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: “ I wish that I might see him once again . Perhaps I could come and go in the night . ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: That 's a terrible thing for a mother to write .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Who has been looking down at the letter — suddenly feeling PETER 'S presence .Who 's that ? Who 's in this room ?Looks over his shoulder — then glances about .I could have sworn somebody was looking over my shoulder ... or had come in at the door ... or ...But seeing no one — he continues .“ I met someone from home ; ... if there is any truth in the rumour of Catherine 's marriage — it must n't be , Mr. Grimm — it must n't be ... not to Frederik . For Frederik is my little boy 's — ”FREDERIK gives a furtive glance upstairs at the door of the child 's room . Picks up the small picture which was in the envelope .Her picture ...Turns it over — looks at the back — reads .FREDERIK , conscious-stricken for the time being , bows his head .“ For my boy , from Annamarie . ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: For the first time since I entered this house , you are yourself , Frederik Grimm . Once more a spark of manhood is alight in your soul . Courage ! It 's not too late to repent . Turn back , lad ! Follow your impulse . Take the little boy in your arms . Go down on your knees and ask his mother 's pardon . Turn over a fresh page , that I may leave this house in peace ....

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Looks about uneasily , then glances towards the door leading into the hall .Who is at the door ? Curious ... I thought I heard someone at ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I am at the door — I , Peter Grimm ! Annamarie is at the door — the little girl who is ashamed to come home ; the old mother in the kitchen breaking her heart for some word . William is at the door — your own flesh and blood — nameless ; Katie , sobbing her heart out — you can hear her ; all — we are all at the door — every soul in this house . We are all at the door of your conscience , Frederik .... Do n't keep us waiting , my boy . It 's very hard to kill the love I had for you . I long to love you again — to take you back to my heart — lies and all .FREDERIK rises — in deep thought .Yes ! Call her ! Tell her the truth . Give her back her promise .... Give her back her home .... Close the door on a peaceful , happy , silent room and go . Think — think of that moment when you give her back her freedom ! Think of her joy , her gratitude , her affection . It 's worth living for , lad . Speak ! Make haste and call her , Fritz .FREDERIK takes several steps — then turns back to the desk . He tears the letter in two , muttering to himself , “ Damn the woman , ” and sinks into his chair .Frederik Grimm , stand up before me !FREDERIK starts to rise , but changes his mind .Stand up !FREDERIK rises — not knowing why he has risen . PETER points an accusing finger at FREDERIK .Liar to the dead ! Cheat , thief , hypocrite ! You sha'n ' t have my little girl . You only want her for a week , a day , an hour . I refuse . I have come back to take her from you and you cannot put me to rest .... I have come back .... You cannot drive me from your thoughts — I am there ....Tapping his forehead , without touching it .I am looking over your shoulder ... in at the window ... under the door .... You are breathing me in the air .... I am looking at your heart .He brings his clenched fist down on the desk in answer to FREDERIK 'S gesture ; but , despite the seeming violence of the blow , he makes no sound .Hear me ! You shall hear me ! Hear me !Calling loudly .Hear me ! Hear me ! Hear me ! Will nobody hear me ? Is there no one in this house to hear me ? No one ? Has my journey been in vain ?...For the first time fully realizing the situation .Oh , must we stand or fall by the mistakes we made here and the deed we did ? Is there no second chance in this world ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: With a sneer on his lips as though trying to banish his thoughts .Psh ! MARTA enters with a tray , containing a pot of coffee and a plate of small cakes . PETER , who has watched her with appealing eyes , like a dog craving attention , glances from her to the desk and from the desk back to MARTA — trying to tempt her to look at the torn letter . FREDERIK , deep in thought , does not notice her . PETER points to the desk as though to say , “ Look ! ” After a pause , she picks up the picture and the letter — holding them in one hand to clear a spot for the tray which she is about to set on the desk .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Speaking in a hushed voice .Marta , see what you have in your hand ... that letter ... there ... read it .... Run to Catherine with it . Read it from the house-tops .... The letter ... Look ! There you have the story of Annamarie .... It is the one way to know the truth in this house — the only way .... There in your hand — the letter .... He will never speak .... The letter for Catherine . MARTA sets down the picture and the letter ; but something prompts her to look at them ; however , before she can carry out her impulse , FREDERIK starts up .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: My God ! How you startled me !MARTA sets down the tray .Oh ! To be off and out of this old rat-trap .He wipes his forehead with his black-bordered handkerchief .I mean — our loss comes home to us so keenly here where we are accustomed to see him .

sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: A cup of coffee , sir ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: No , no , no .

sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: Pathetically .I thought you wished to keep to your uncle 's customs .... He always took it at this time .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Recovering .Yes , yes , of course .

sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: No word ?...

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Hesitates .What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: No letter ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Letter ?...Covering the letter with his hand .From whom ?...

sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: From ... At a time like this , I thought ... I felt ... that Annamarie ... that there should be some message .... Every day I expect to hear ...

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: No . PETER gestures to MARTA — pointing to the picture and letter , now covered by FREDERIK 'S hand .

sp.speaker: MARTA
sp.p: Hesitating .Are you certain ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Quite certain .She curtsies and leaves the room . FREDERIK , as though relieved to see her go , jumps to his feet , and , tearing the letter in smaller pieces , lights them in the candle , dropping the burning pieces on a tray . As the flame dies out , FREDERIK brushes the blackened paper into the waste-basket .There 's an end to that ! PETER crouches near the basket — hovering over it , his hinds clasped helplessly . After a pause , he raises his hand , until it points to a bedroom above . An echo of the circus music is very faintly heard ; not with the blaring of brasses , but with the sounds of elfin horns , conveying the impression of a phantom circus band . The door of WILLIAM 'S room opens , and he comes out as though to listen to the music . He wears a sleeping suit and is bare-footed . He has come down stairs before FREDERIK sees him . FREDERIK quickly puts aside the photograph , laying it on the desk , covering it with his hand .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Gruffly .Why are n't you in bed ? If you 're ill , that 's the proper place for you .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I came down to hear the circus music .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Circus music ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: It woke me up .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: The circus left town days ago . You must have been dreaming .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: The band 's playing now . Do n't you hear it , sir ? The procession 's passing .He runs to the window and opens it . The music stops . A breeze sweeps through the room — bellies out the curtains and causes the lustres to jingle on the mantel . Surprised .No . It 's almost dark . There 's no procession ... no shining horses ....Turning sadly away from the window .Rubbing his eyes .I wonder what made me think the — I must have been dreaming .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Goes to the window , closes it . The child looks at him and , in retreating from him , unconsciously backs towards PETER .Are you feeling better ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Yes , sir , I feel better — and hungry .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Go back to bed .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: FREDERIK sits .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Where 's your mother , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Do you know where Annamarie is ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Why do you ask me ? What should I know of her ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Grandmother does n't know ; Miss Catherine does n't know ; nobody knows .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Tears up the picture — turning so that WILLIAM does not see what he is doing . PETER , who has been smiling at WILLIAM , motions him to come nearer . WILLIAM , feeling PETER 'S presence , looks round the room .I do n't know , either .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Mr. Frederik , where 's old Mr. Grimm ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Dead .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Puzzled — unable to explain himself , he hesitates .Are you sure he 's dead ? ‘ Cause —

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Annoyed ..You 'd better go to bed .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Pointing to a glass of water on a tray .Can I have a drink of water , please ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Go to bed , sir , or you 'll be punished . Water 's not good for little boys with fever .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Going towards the stairs .Goes slowly up the stairs . FREDERIK would destroy the pieces of the picture ; but PETER faces him as though forbidding him to touch it , and , for the first time , FREDERIK imagines he sees the apparition of his uncle .Wish I could find a cold brook and lie in it .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: In a very low voice — almost inaudibly .Receding a step and yet another step as the vision of PETER is still before him , he passes out of the room , wiping the beads of sweat from his forehead . WILLIAM , hearing the door close , comes down stairs and , running to the table at back , drinks a glass of water .My God ! I thought I saw ...

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Um ! That 's good !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: WILLIAM does n't see PETER yet , but he feels his influence .William !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Wish it had been the circus music .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You shall hear it all again .Gestures towards the plate of cakes on the tray .Come , William , here 's something very nice .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Seeing the cakes .He steals to the tray , looking over his shoulder in fear of being caught .Um ! Cakes !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Do n't be frightened . I 'm here to protect you . Help yourself to the cakes . William , do you think you could deliver a message for me ... a very important message ?... The circus music is heard . WILLIAM sits at the tray and PETER seats himself opposite as though he were the host doing the honours . WILLIAM , being unconsciously coaxed by PETER , is prevailed upon to choose the biggest cake . He takes a bite , looking towards PETER .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: To himself .Ha !... Think I am dreaming .Rubbing his little stomach ecstatically .Hope I wo n't wake up and find there was n't any cake .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Do n't worry , you wo n't .WILLIAM has taken another piece of cake which he nibbles at — now holding a piece in each hand .Pretty substantial dream , eh ? There 's a fine , fat raisin .WILLIAM eats the raisin , then looks into the sugar-bowl .Do n't hesitate , William . Sugar wo n't hurt you now . Nothing can hurt you any more . Fall to , William — help yourself .WILLIAM looks over his shoulder , fearing the return of FREDERIK .Oh , he wo n't come back in a hurry . Ha ! Frederik thought he saw me , William ; well , he did n't . He had a bad conscience — hallucination .WILLIAM nibbles a lump of sugar .Now , William , I have a message for you . Wo n't you try and take it for me , eh ?But WILLIAM eats another lump of sugar .I see ... I can n't expect to get any assistance from a boy while his little stomach 's calling .WILLIAM empties the cream jug and helps himself to cakes . Presently the music dies out .Now I 'm going to tell you something .Impressively .You 're a very lucky boy , William ; I congratulate you . Do you know why — of all this household — you are the only one to help me ?... This is the secret : in a little time — it wo n't be long — you 're going —As though he were imparting the most delightful information .— to know better ! Think of that ! Is n't the news splendid ?But WILLIAM eats on .Think of what most of us have to endure before we know better ! Why , William , you 're going into the circus without paying for a ticket . You 're laying down the burden before you climb the hill . And in your case , William , you are fortunate indeed ; for there are some little soldiers in this world already handicapped when they begin the battle of life .... Their parents have n't fitted them for the struggle .... Like little moon moths ,— they look in at the windows ; they beat at the panes ; they see the lights of happy firesides — the lights of home ; but they never get in .... You are one of these wanderers , William .... And so , it is well for you that before your playing time is over — before your man 's work begins ,— you 're going to know the great secret . Happy boy ! No coarsening of your child 's heart , until you stand before the world like Frederik ; no sweat and toil such as dear old James is facing ; no dimming of the eye and trembling of the hand such as the poor old Doctor shall know in time to come ; no hot tears to blister your eyes , ... tears such as Katie is shedding now ; but , in all your youth , your faith — your innocence ,— you 'll fall asleep and oh ! the awakening , William !... “ It is well with the child . ”WILLIAM lays down the cake and , clasping his hands , thinks . PETER answers his thoughts .What ? No — do n't think of it ! Nonsense ! You do n't want to grow up to be a man . Grow up to fail ? Or , still worse — to succeed — to be famous ? To wear a heavy laurel wreath ? A wreath to be held up by tired hands that ache for one hour 's freedom . No , no , you 're to escape all that , William ; joy is on the way to meet you with sweets in its outstretched hands and laughter on its lips .WILLIAM takes the last swallow of a piece of cake , exclaims “ Hm ! ” in a satisfied way , brushes the crumbs off his lap , and sits back in his chair .Have you had enough ? Good ! William , I want you to try to understand that you 're to help me , will you ? Will you tell Miss Catherine that —

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Without looking up , his hands folded in his lap .Take me back with you , Mr. Grimm ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Can you see me , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: No , sir ; but I know .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Come here .WILLIAM does n't move .Here ... here ...WILLIAM advances to the center of the room and pauses hesitatingly .Take my hand ...WILLIAM approaches in the direction of the voice . PETER takes WILLIAM 'S outstretched hand .Have you got it ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: No , sir ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Putting his hand on WILLIAM 'S head .Now ?... Do you feel it ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I feel something , yes , sir .Puts his hand on PETER 'S hand , which is still on his head .But where 's your hand ? There 's nothing there .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: But you hear me ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I can n't really hear you .... It 's a dream .Coaxingly .Oh , Mr. Grimm , take me back with you .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You 're not quite ready to go with me yet , William — not until we can see each other face to face .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Why did you come back , Mr. Grimm ? Was n't it nice where you were ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: It was indeed . It was like —Whimsically .— new toys .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: To whom the idea appeals .As nice as that !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Indicating the picture .Nicer . But I had to come back with this message . I want you to help me to deliver it .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Where 's the bosom of Abraham , Mr. Grimm ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: The minister says you 're asleep there .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Stuff and nonsense ! I have n't been near the bosom of Abraham .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Too bad you died before you went to the circus , Mr. Grimm . But it must be great to be in a place where you can look down and see the circus for nothing . Do you remember the clown that sang : “ Uncle Rat has gone to town ? ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , indeed ; but let us talk of something more important . Come here , WilliamHe starts towards the desk .PETER is standing at the desk with his finger on the torn pieces of the picture .; would you like to see someone whom all little boys love — love more than anybody else in the whole world ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Yes , the clown in the circus .... No ... it is n't a clown ; ... it 's our mother .... Yes , I want to see my mother , Annamarie .Unconsciously WILLIAM comes to the desk and sees the torn picture — picks up a piece and looks at it . Very simply .Why ... there she is !... That 's her face .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ah ! You recognize her . Mother 's face is there , William , but it 's in little bits . We must put her together , William . We must show her to everybody in the house , so that everybody will say : “ How in the world did she ever get here ? To whom does this picture belong ? ” We must set them to thinking .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Yes . Let us show her to everybody .He sits and joins the pieces under the guidance of PETER .Annamarie ... Annamarie ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You remember many things , William ... things that happened when you lived with Annamarie , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I was very little ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Still , you remember ....

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Evasively .I was afraid ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You loved her .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: To picture .Oh , yes ... yes , I loved you .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Now , through that miracle of love , you can remember many things tucked away in your childish brain ,— things laid away in your mind like toys upon a shelf . Come , pick them up and dust them off and bring them out again . It will come back . When you lived with Annamarie ... there was you ... and Annamarie ... and —

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: — and the other one .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ah ! We 're getting nearer ! Who was the other one ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Gives a quick glance towards the door — then as though speaking to the picture .I must put you together before he comes back .He fits the other pieces together — PETER trying to guide him . Presently WILLIAM hums as a child will when at play , singing the tune of “ Uncle Rat . ”“ Uncle Rat has gone to town . ” PETER and WILLIAM .Singing together .At this instant , PETER is indicating another piece of the picture .“ Ha ! H 'm ! ”

lg.l: Her other foot .
“ Uncle Rat has gone to town ,
To buy his niece a wedding gown . ”
lg.stage: Adjusting a piece of the picture .
lg.l: Her hand .
WILLIAM and PETER .
“ Ha ! H 'm ! ”

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Her other hand .Sings .“ What shall the wedding breakfast be ? Hard boiled eggs and — ”Speaking .WILLIAM pauses — looking for a piece of the picture .Where 's —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Finishing the verse .With a gesture as though knocking on the door of the adjoining room to attract MRS. BATHOLOMMEY 'S attention .“ A cup of tea . ”

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Speaks .There 's her hat . WILLIAM and PETER .Singing .“ Ha ! H 'm ! ”

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Stops singing and claps his hands with boyish delight — staring at the picture .Annamarie ! Annamarie ! You 're not in bits any more — you 're all put together . By this time , PETER is going up the stairs , and , as he stands in front of CATHERINE 'S door , it opens . PETER passes in and CATHERINE comes out .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Astonished .Why , William ! What are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Miss Catherine ! Come down ! Come down ! I have something to show you .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Not coming down .Passes into WILLIAM 'S room .No , dear — come upstairs ; there 's a good boy . You must n't play down there . Come to bed .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Who has entered , and sees WILLIAM ..William !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Look — look !Pointing to the picture .See what old Mr. Grimm brought back with him .

lg.l: What are you talking about , William ? Old
Mr. Grimm is dead .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: No , he is n't ; ... he 's come back .... He has been in this room .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Absurd !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I was talking to him .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: You 're feverish again . I must get the Doctor .Comes down to WILLIAM .And I thought you were feeling better !Seeing CATHERINE , who appears on the balcony as though wondering why WILLIAM does n't come to bed .The child 's mind is wandering . He imagines all sorts of things . I 'll call the Doctor —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Who has re-entered .You need n't — he 's coming now . Come in , Andrew . I 'm giving you one more chance . The DOCTOR enters , wearing his skull-cap , and carrying his pipe in his hand . It is evident that he has come over in a hurry .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Surprised .I was just going for you . How fortunate that you came .

lg.l: I thought I 'd have another peep at William .
By this time , CATHERINE has seated herself on a chair , and takes
WILLIAM on her lap . He puts his arms round her neck .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: He 's quite delirious .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Does n't look it .Putting his hand on WILLIAM 'S cheek and forehead .Taking WILLIAM 'S pulse .Very slight fever . What makes you think he was delirious ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Interrupting .He said that old Mr. Grimm was in this room — that he was talking to him .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Interested .Yes ? Really ? Well , possibly he is . Nothing remarkable in that , is there ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well , at last !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: What ? Oh , of course , you believe in —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: In fact , I had a compact with him to return if —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: A compact ? Of all the preposterous —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Not at all . Dozens of cases on record — as I can show you — where these compacts have actually been kept .Suddenly struck — looking at WILLIAM .I wonder if that boy 's a sensitive .Hand on his chin .I wonder ...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Echoing the DOCTOR 'S words .A sensitive ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: It 's difficult to explain . I mean a human organism so constituted that it can be informed or controlled by those who — er — have —With a gesture .crossed over .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I think I 'll put the boy to bed , Doctor .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Just a moment , Mistress Batholommey . I 'm here to find out what ails William . William , what makes you think that Mr. Grimm is in this room ?

lg.l: I would n't have the child encouraged in such ideas ,
Catherine . I —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Sh ! Please , please .Taking the boy on his knee .What makes you think Peter Grimm is in this room ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Hesitating .The things he said to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Said to you ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Wonderingly .William , ... are you sure he ...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Said to you , eh ?WILLIAM nods assent .Old Mr. Grimm ?WILLIAM nods .Sure of that , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Oh . yes , sir .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Think before you speak , my boy ; what did Mr. Grimm say to you ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Lots of things ...

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Really !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Raises his hand for silence .How did he look , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I did n't see him .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Ha !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: You must have seen something .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I thought once I saw his hat on the peg where it used to hang .Looks at the peg .No , it 's gone .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Remonstrating .Doctor !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Thinking .I wonder if he really did —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Do you think he could have seen Uncle Peter ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Pointing to the desk .William !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Look ! ...Points to the picture .That 's what I wanted to show you when you were upstairs .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Seeing the picture .It 's his mother — Annamarie .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: The Lord save us — his mother ! I did n't know you 'd heard from Annamarie .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: We have n't .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Then how 'd that picture get into the house ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ah ! I knew she 'd begin ! Now that she 's wound up , we shall get at the truth .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: It 's a new picture . She 's much changed . How ever did it find its way here ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I never saw it before . It 's very strange .... We 've all been waiting for news of her . Even her mother does n't know where she is , or — could Marta have received this since I —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Exit into dining-room .I 'll ask her .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: If not , who had the picture ?... And why were n't we all told ?... Who tore it up ? Did you , William ?WILLIAM shakes his head , meaning “ No . ”She pauses — perplexed .Who has been at the desk ? No one save Frederik ... Frederik ... and surely he —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Re-entering .No , Marta has n't heard a word ; and , only a few minutes ago , she asked Frederik if some message had n't come , but he said “ No , nothing . ” I did n't tell her of the picture .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Looking at the picture .I wonder if there was any message with it .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I remember the day that picture came ... the day your uncle died .... It was in a long blue envelope — the size of the picture .... I took it from the postman myself because every one was distracted and rushing about . It dropped to the floor and as I picked it up I thought I knew the writing ; but I could n't remember whose it was .... It was directed to your uncle ....Looking from the desk to the waste-basket .There 's the envelopeHolding up a scrap of blue envelope .and paper ; ... some one has burned it .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Annamarie wrote to my uncle ...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Not understanding .But what could Peter have to say to me concerning Annamarie ?Making a resolution — rising .We 're going to find out . You may draw the curtains , Catherine , if you please .CATHERINE draws the curtains . The DOCTOR turns the lights down and closes the door . A pause .Peter Grimm ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , Andrew ?...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Not hearing .If you have come back ... if you are in the room ... and the boy speaks truly — give me some sign ... some indication ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I can n't give you a sign , Andrew .... I have spoken to the boy ... the boy ...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: If you cannot make your presence known to me — I know there are great difficulties — will you try and send your message by William ? I presume you have one —

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , that 's right .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: — or else you would n't have come back .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: That 's just the point I wanted to make , Andrew . You understand perfectly .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: As before .I am waiting .... We are all waiting .Noticing that a door is a trifle ajar .MRS. BATHOLOMMEY , without making a sound , closes it and sits as before .The door 's open again .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: A pause .Sh ! Listen !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: In a peculiar manner — as though in a half dream — but not shutting his eyes . As though controlled by PETER .There was Annamarie and me and the other .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Very low , as though afraid to interrupt WILLIAM 'S train of thought .What other ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: The man ... that came .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: What man ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: The man that made Annamarie cry .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Who was he ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I do n't know ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , you do . Do n't tell lies , William .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: What man made Annamarie cry ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I can n't remember ....

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , you can .... You 're afraid ....

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: In a low voice .So you do remember the time when you lived with Annamarie ; ... you always told me that you did n't ...To DR. MACPHERSON .I must know more of this —Pauses abruptly .Think , William , who came to the house ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: That 's what I asked you , William .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: That 's what he asked ...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Mr. Grimm .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: When , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Just now ... CATHERINE and MRS. BATHOLOMMEY .Together .Just now !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: H 'm .... You both ask the same question , eh ? The man that came to see —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Perplexed .It can n't be possible that the child knows what he 's talking about .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Ignoring her .What did you tell Mr. Grimm when he asked you ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You 'd better make haste , William . Frederik is coming back .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Looking uneasily over his shoulder .I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Why does he always look towards that door ? You 're not afraid now , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Looking towards the door .N-no — but .... Please , please do n't let Mr. Frederik come back . ‘ Cause then I 'll be afraid again .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: William ! William !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Rising quickly .Yes , Mr. Grimm ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: You must say that I am very unhappy .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: He says he is very unhappy .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Why is he unhappy ?... Ask him .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Why are you unhappy , Mr. Grimm ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I am thinking of Catherine 's future ....

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Not understanding the last word — puzzled .Eh ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: To-morrow ...

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: After a slight pause .To-morrow ...

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Catherine 's —

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Looks at CATHERINE — hesitating .Stops . CATHERINE gives the DOCTOR a quick glance — she seems to divine the message .Your —

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Prompting .Her —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: What , William ? What of to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: She must not marry Frederik .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I must n't say that .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Points towards PETER . All instinctively look towards the spot to which WILLIAM points , but they see no one .What he wanted me to say .

lg.l: Catherine — must — not — marry
Frederik Grimm .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Speak , William . No one will hurt you .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Oh , yes , he will ....Looking timidly towards the door FREDERIK passed through .I do n't want to tell his name — ‘ cause ... ‘ cause ...

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Why do n't you tell the name , William ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Make haste , William , make haste .

lg.l: I 'm afraid ... I 'm afraid ... he will make
Annamarie cry ; ... he makes me cry ...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: With suppressed excitement — half to herself .Why are you afraid of him ? Was Frederik the man that came to see Annamarie ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Catherine !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: On her knees before WILLIAM .Was he ? Was it Frederik Grimm ? Tell me , William .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Surely you do n't believe ...

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: In a low voice .I 've thought of a great many things to-day ... little things ... little things I 'd never noticed before .... I 'm putting them together just as he put that picture together .... I must know the truth .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: William , make haste .... Frederik is listening at the door .

lg.stage: He looks over his shoulder and CATHERINE goes towards the door .
lg.l: I wo n't say any more . He 's there ... at the door

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: William , tell me .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: William ! CATHERINE opens the door suddenly . FREDERIK is standing , listening . He is taken unawares and for a few seconds he does not move — then he recovers .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Please do n't let him scold me . I 'm afraid of him .Going towards the stairs — looking at FREDERIK .I was afraid of him when I lived with Annamarie and he came to see us and made her cry .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Are you sure you remember that ? Were n't you too small ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Goes upstairs .No , I do remember .... I always did remember ; only for a little while I — I forgot .... I must go to bed . He told me to .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Calling after WILLIAM .WILLIAM goes to his room .You 're a good boy , William .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: After a slight pause — simply .Frederik , you 've heard from Annamarie ....Gestures towards the desk . FREDERIK sees the photograph and is silent .You 've had a letter from her . You tried to destroy it . Why did you tell Marta that you 'd had no message — no news ? You went to see her , too . Why did you tell me that you 'd never seen her since she went away ? Why did you lie to me ? Why do you hate that child ?

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Are you going to believe what that boy —

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I 'm going to find out . I 'm going to find out where she is , before I marry you . That child may be right or wrong ; but I 'm going to know what his mother was to you . I want the truth .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Who has been in thought — now looking up .We 've heard the truth . We had that message from Peter Grimm himself .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Yes , it is true . I believe Uncle Peter Grimm was in this room to-night .

sp.speaker: FREDERIK
sp.p: Not surprised — glancing towards the spot where PETER stood when he thought he saw him .Oh ! You , too ? Did you see him , too ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Incredulously .Impossible !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I do n't care what anyone else may think — people have the right to think for themselves ; but I believe he has been here — he is here . Uncle Peter , if you can hear me now , give me back my promise — or — or I 'll take it back !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Gently — smilingly — relieved .I did give it back to you , my dear ; but what a time I have had getting it across !

div.head: ACT III .

stage.stage: The third act takes place at twenty minutes to twelve on the same night .

The fire is out . The table on which PETER took his coffee in the first act is now being used by the DOCTOR for WILLIAM 'S medicines , two bottles , two glasses , two teaspoons , a clinical thermometer , & c. WILLIAM , who has been questioned by the DOCTOR , is now asleep upstairs . PETER 'S hat hangs on the peg in the shadow . Although the hour is late , no one has thought of going to bed . FREDERIK is waiting at the hotel for the lawyer whom HICKS was to send to arrange for the sale of PETER GRIMM 'S nurseries , but he has not arrived . The DOCTOR , full of his theories , is seated before the fire , writing the account of PETER GRIMM 'S return , for the American Branch of the “ London Society for Psychical Research . ” It is now a fine , clear night . The clouds are almost silvery and a hint of the moon is showing .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Reading what he has written .“ To be forwarded to the ‘ London Society for Psychical Research ': Dr. Hyslop : Dear Sir : This evening at the residence of Peter — ”Pauses and inserts “ the late ” and continues to read after inserting the words .“ — the late Peter Grimm — the well-known horticulturist of Grimm Manor , New York , certain phenomena were observed which would clearly indicate the return of Peter Grimm , ten days after his decease . While he was invisible to all , three people were present besides myself — one of these , a child of eight , who received the message . No spelling out by signals nor automatic writing was employed , but word of mouth . ”A rap sounds .Who will that be at this hour ?...Looks at the clock .Nearly midnight .Opening the door .Yes ?

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Outside .Telegram for Frederik Grimm .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Not in . I 'll sign .He signs and , receiving the telegram , sets it against a candle-stick on the desk and resumes his seat . Reads :“ I made a compact with Peter Grimm , while he was in the flesh , that whichever went first was to return and give the other some sign ; and I propose to give positive proof — ”He hesitates — thinks — then repeats .“ positive proof that he kept this compact and that I assisted in the carrying out of his instructions . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Enters — evidently highly wrought up by the events of the evening .Who was that ? Who knocked ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Telegram .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I thought perhaps Frederik had come back . Do n't you consider William much better ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Mm ...

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Dear , dear ! The scene that took place to-night has completely upset me .The DOCTOR takes up his pen and reads to himself .Well , Doctor :She pushes forward a chair and sits at the other side of the table — facing him .the breaking off of the engagement is rather sudden , is n't it ? We 've been talking it over in the front parlour , Mr. Batholommey and I. James has finished his work and has just joined us . I suggest sending out a card — a neat card — saying that , owing to the bereavement in the family , the wedding has been indefinitely postponed . Of course , it is n't exactly true .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Goes on reading .Wo n't take place at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Evidently not ; but if the whole matter looks very strange to me — how is it going to look to other people ; especially when we have n't any — any rational explanation — as yet ? We must get out of it in some fashion .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Whose business is it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Nobody 's , of course . But Catherine 's position is certainly unusual ; and the strangest part of it all is — she does n't seem to feel her situation . She 's sitting alone in the library , seemingly placid and happy . What I really wish to consult you about is this : should n't the card we 're going to send out have a narrow black border ?The DOCTOR is now writing .Doctor , you do n't appear to be interested . You might at least answer my question .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: What chance have I had to answer ? You 've done all the talking .

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Rising — annoyed .Oh , of course , all these little matters sound trivial to you ; but men like you could n't look after the workings of the next world if other people did n't attend to this . Some one has to do it .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: I fully appreciate the fact , Mistress Batholommey , that other people are making it possible for me to be myself . I 'll admit that ; and now if I might have a few moments in peace to attend to something really important —

div.stage: The REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY has entered with his hat in his hand .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Doctor , I 've been thinking things over . I ran in for a moment to suggest that we suspend judgment until the information William has volunteered can be verified . I can scarcely believe that —

lg.l: Ump !
lg.stage: Rises and goes to the telephone on the desk .
lg.l: Four-red .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: I regret that Frederik left the house without offering some explanation .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: At the ‘ phone .Seats himself at the table .Marget , I 'm at Peter 's . I mean — I 'm at the Grimms ’ . Send me my bag . I 'll stay the night with William . Bye .

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Tell Frederik that , if he cares to consult me , I shall be at home in my study . Good-night , Doctor . Good-night , Rose .

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: Hold on , Mr. Batholommey !The REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY turns .I 'm writing an account of all that 's happened here to-night —

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Dubiously .Indeed !

sp.speaker: DR. MACPHERSON
sp.p: I shall verify every word of the evidence by William 's mother for whom I am searching .The REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY smiles faintly behind his hand .Then I shall send in my report , and not until then . What I wish to ask is this : would you have any objection to the name of Mrs. Batholommey being used as a witness ?

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Looks perplexed .Well ,— er — a —

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Oh , no , you do n't ! You may flout our beliefs ; but would n't you like to bolster up your report with “ the wife of a clergyman who was present ! ” It sounds so respectable and sane , does n't it ? No , sir ! You cannot prop up your wild-eyed —

sp.speaker: REV . MR. BATHOLOMMEY
sp.p: Rose , my dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. BATHOLOMMEY
